Review_body: Pompeii may very well have earned the title as the first suburb albeit it was some miles from Rome, near where Naples is now. It was a pleasure city where the rich and powerful of Rome came to relax and indulge the vices. Being near Mount Versuvius it was warm there all the time with thermal like heat underground. But in 79 AD Versuvius erupted and the place was destroyed.If you're expecting to see something like a remake of The Last Days Of Pompeii I'd forget that notion. The last third of the film Pompeii comes down and Versuvius erupts with some nice computer graphic spectacle. But the plot is a skimpy one, about a slave boy turned gladiator and the patrician woman who thinks he's something special in those gladiator tights. Boy and girl are Kit Anderson and Emily Browning.Villain of the piece in a truly classic Snidely Whiplash is Kiefer Sutherland who chewed the scenery which is what you do when in a turkey. He's a corrupt Roman Senator who wants to take Browning back to Rome as a trophy wife. Not if our gladiator hero can help it. Then the volcano erupts and everybody's got bigger problems.You'll like the spectacle, but the story is a ball of corn.

I was excited about POMPEII the film, that is until I found out resident Hollywood hack Paul W. S. Anderson (he of the rubbishy RESIDENT EVIL films) was directing. What could have been a taut, effects-fuelled thriller along the lines of a historical DANTE'S PEAK turns instead into a CGI fest, a snoozer with a clichéd plot, even more clichéd characters, and an entire lack of the things that make thrillers work: I'm talking suspense, danger, and excitement.The first hour of the film has nothing to do with a volcano at all. Instead we get yet another retread of the usual Gladiator/Spartacus type plot line, in which a fictional gladiator falls in love with a Roman noblewoman and comes under the attention of an evil senator. Kit Harington, so good in GAME OF THRONES, is extraordinarily wooden here, while Emily Browning is one of the least convincing Romans ever put on screen.Eventually the volcano stuff hits, and it's all CGI spectacle as you'd imagine. The effects aren't bad at all, but Anderson remains as bad a director as ever, shooting the action in cheesy, unbelievable ways with his incessant slow motion and the like. The abrupt ending will make you laugh out loud. Kiefer Sutherland's bad guy is straight out of a pantomime, and of the cast, only Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje has anything approaching a half-decent character.

Review title: Spartacus TV show and a disaster movie
Review_body: Milo (Kit Harington) is the new slave gladiator called The Celt. As a child, his Celtic Horse tribe village in Northern Britannia was massacred by Corvus (Kiefer Sutherland) and his right hand man Proculus (Sasha Roiz). He catches the eye of Cassia (Emily Browning) as she travels home to Pompeii. He is to face Atticus (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje) who is one victory away from gaining his freedom. Corvus arrives in Pompeii as a Senator. Cassia's parents Aurelia (Carrie-Anne Moss) and Severus (Jared Harris) need Corvus' help to build new constructions for the city. Cruel Corvus is obsessed with Cassia and has followed her from Rome.This is reminiscent of the Spartacus TV show except it is a poorer version. The characters are barely compelling enough to keep my attention. Kiefer Sutherland is not a good villain at least not in this movie. The disaster movie doesn't improve anything. It becomes a CGI extravaganza and it overwhelms what's left of the characters. People separate and reconnect out of nowhere. The movie should really keep the group together.

It is Gladiator meets Volcano as Hollywood Hack Paul W S Anderson once again strives to make a passable film and fails.Milo (Kit Harington) is a slave called the Celt from ancient Briton was as a child saw his people massacred by cruel Corvus (Kiefer Sutherland.)Milo is now a gladiator brought to Pompeii as the nearby mountain is about to erupt. Milo is due to battle mighty Atticus (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje) who needs just one more victory to become free.Milo's horse whispering abilities has also brings him close to a roman woman Cassia (Emily Browning) as she arrives in Pompeii to be with her wealthy family. Hot on her heels is Corvus, who wants to marry Cassia and is the new senator of Pompeii.However as Pompeii spews its volcanic ash, Milo sees his chance to get revenge on Corvus.The film is utter tosh. The first hour is a thin story with zero characterisation. The second hour moves from Gladiator to a Roman disaster story.

In 79 A.D., a Celtic tribe of horsemen is slaughtered by the Roman Senator Corvus (Kiefer Sutherland), his right-hand man Proculus (Sasha Roiz) and their army. The boy Milo is the only survivor that is captured later and sold as slave. Seventeen years later, the slave Milo (Kit Harington) turns into an invincible gladiator in a province and is brought to Pompeii to participate in the games in the arena. While walking to Pompeii, the noble Cassia (Emily Browning) and her chaperone Ariadne (Jessica Lucas) cross with the path of the slaves and Cassia is fascinated by Milo. He shares the cell of Atticus (Adewale Akinnuoye- Agbaje), who is near to get his freedom depending on winning his last fight. Meanwhile Cassia meets her parents Severus (Jared Harris) and Aurelia (Carrie-Anne Moss) and learns that she has been betrothed to the corrupt Senator Corvus that is pressing her parents to marry her. During the games, the Mount Vesuvius erupts and Milos and his friend Atticus succeed to escape from the arena. But Milo wants to save his beloved Cassia in the middle of the chaos and the Romans. "Pompeii" is a full of action and dull romance in the tragic environment of the last days of Pompeii. Disaster movies were popular in the 70's ("Airport", "The Towering Inferno", and "Earthquake" among others) and Paul W.S. Anderson returns to the genre after "Titanic". The entertaining story is silly with poor lines and dialogs, but never boring. Kit Harington, the "Jon Snow" from "Games of Thrones", makes it worth to see at least on DVD. My vote is six.Title (Brazil): "Pompeia" ("Pompeii")

Review title: Like Titanic, we know how this ends
Review_body:
The film attempts to develop an interesting love story to the background of Pompeii. Celt (Kit Harington) is taken prisoner by the Romans after they wiped out his village. He grew up fighting in the London arena. He is whisked away to Pompeii years later where his great strength as a gladiator and his ability as a horse whisperer catches the attention of a woman of wealth (Emily Browning). As it just so happens, she is being forced to marry the Senator (Kiefer Sutherland) a man who slaughtered Celt's village. Is there a writer in the house?The love story never evolved. Like most fighters, Celt has no trouble with 12 men, but takes him much longer fighting one man. There are no real political statements in the film. Celt believes his gods are punishing Rome, blah.blah, blah.
No F-bombs, sex, or nudity

We do know about Pompeii I assume, so I don't consider this a spoiler. If you don't know about it, don't read on and complain afterward. Having that out of the way, everyone knows where this is going, so why watch it? Is it the 3D then? Maybe. I don't expect it to be the actors (even though you have Jack Bauer ... I mean Kiefer Southerland in it).The pretty young lady then, that must be it? No? The "Spartacus" (TV-show) inspired Gladiator sub-story, that must be it! Less bloody not as exciting. No can't be that either. The predictable story (apart from the volcano eruption at the end)? I guess if you want easy ... but to be serious for a second, the big draw can only be the special effects (though they haven't managed to put emotion into actors faces yet ... not believable ones at least).So if you're in for a "fun ride", you might feel comfortable, even with the paper thin story you get served, the family friendly love story, the "violence" and the Uber villain, who normally wouldn't spend 2 minutes of his 24 hours doing things like this ... your choice!

I saw the trailer for this film months before the film was to be released, it looked like it was going to be one of the big blockbusters of the year, I was definitely up for seeing a historical disaster movie, from director Paul W.S. Anderson (Mortal Kombat, Resident Evil, AVP: Alien vs. Predator, Death Race). Basically, set in 79 A.D., Britannia, Milo (Game of Throne's Kit Harington) as a child witnessed Celtic horsemen kill all in his tribe, and their Roman leader Corvus (Kiefer Sutherland) murder his mother personally, he was captured, and seventeen years he has turned from slave to gladiator. Slave owner Graecus (Joe Pingue) takes him and fellow slaves to the city of Pompeii, on the journey he catches the eye of Cassia (Sucker Punch's Emily Browning), the beautiful daughter of merchant and city ruler Severus (The Quiet Ones' Jared Harris) and his wife Aurelia (The Matrix's Carrie-Anne Moss). The city, compared to being like a "summer holiday resort", is situated near the base of volcano Mount Vesuvius, previously the city has only experienced light earthquakes and rumbles, but unaware to everyone the mountain is warming up to make a significant devastation, starting with a quake opening up the earth outside the city and killing servant Felix (Dalmar Abuzeid). At the gladiatorial arena Milo meets and shares a cell with fellow slave and champion gladiator Atticus (Lost's Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje), at first the two are rivals, but they form a friendship, and Milo gets another opportunity to see Cassia, taking her for a ride, it is obvious they are holding back potential feelings, they are interrupted, but he is not killed, she pleads his life is spared by Corvus, but he is lashed as punishment. Milo's punishment continues as he and Atticus along with other gladiators are chained to rocks in the Amphitheatre of Pompeii to battle against Roman soldiers, Atticus realises his promise of freedom will not happen, and while watching Cassia is forced into agreeing marrying Corvus, or her parents will be killed as punishment for treason to the Emperor. She again defies the order from Corvus to have Milo killed, more powerful earthquakes occur, he calms the audience down and has his officer Proculus (Sasha Roiz) face Milo in a one-on-one fight, this is interrupted when Mount Vesuvius finally explodes, the powerful quakes cause the stadium to collapse, and everyone is panicking in the devastation. Milo and Proculus retreat to the jail levels of the arena, Milo releases Atticus and all gladiators opening their cell gates, giving them the chance to attack their captors, Proculus escapes and wicked gladiator trainer Bellator (Currie Graham) is killed, Corvus is trapped under a fallen beam, Severus tries to kill him, but Corvus stabs him and then manages to escape. Balls of fire are unleashed on the city and everyone is fleeing to the harbour, Graecus is killed on one of the ships by a fireball, before dying Aurelia tells Milo that Cassia is at the villa, he races to rescue her and her servant Ariadne (Evil Dead's Jessica Lucas), she saves his love interest but the servant is killed when ground collapses below her into the sea. While Corvus and Proculus kill civilians getting in their way of reaching safety, Atticus is also trying to reach the harbour, but a tsunami created by the volcano rushes towards the city, destroying everything in it's path, he barely rescues a little girl from the tidal wave as the people reenter the high walls where the water stops. Milo and Atticus are reunited, and knowing that they cannot escape by sea they decide to search for horses to ride to the south, so they return to the stadium to find them, Cassia finds her dead parents, and then Corvus appears and kidnaps her, Atticus tells his friend to chase after her while he faces Proculus, the Roman manages to mortally wound the gladiator, but he rises up and stabs him in the neck with his broken blade and kills the soldier. Barely avoiding the falling fireballs and collapsing ground, the chase goes through the falling Pomepii streets, the chariot crashes into the Temple of Aollo, Cassia managed to release herself before this, the temple is destroyed by a fireball as Corvus and Milo battle, Cassia chains the corrupt leader up and the couple ride off and leave him behind. The volcano makes it's much bigger explosion and creates a pyroclastic surge that races toward Pompeii, Corvus is incinerated, Atticus proudly meets his fate proclaiming he will die a free man, and at the outskirts of the city Milo and Cassia are thrown of their horse, he tells her to ride off on her own, but she does not want to spend her last moments running, they passionately kiss as they are engulfed by the blast, their bodies are plaster casts locked in an eternal embrace. Harington makes good of being the young horse whispering slave hero, Browning is a good choice as the beautiful heroine, Sutherland is lovably cheesy with the naff British accent being a near pantomime villain, and Akinnuoye-Agbaje is always the reliable character actor and was my favourite as the gruff but good-hearted gladiator. It does the same as Titanic, you stick a fictional love story and other bits and pieces in a true and devastating event in history, in this case the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, and there you go, we all know that it is not going end happily, the story is predictable and full of camp stuff, but in a good way, and of course once the disaster propels it does not stop, the special effects to create the explosive volcanic activity is fantastic, a most entertaining action adventure. Good!

Most of the reviews capture the main elements of the movie. If it missed a cliché, I missed the missing of it. Just an example. We know that in slasher movies the supposedly dead villain leaps back to life. The earliest and best example of such an event is from "Wait Until Dark" (1967). Here, one of the more dislikable heavies -- Kiefer Sutherland as the pompous representative of Rome -- gets to pull the stunt twice.There are three blacks in the movie. They're all friends and caretakers of the white people. One by one, they are picked off. Usually the white hero and heroine (Kit Harrington and Emily Browning) get away alive, but in this case everyone perishes, with the two lovers turned into upright statues of ash.Those clumsy looking human forms that we've all seen from Pompeii are interesting. None were upright, of course. Pompeii was buried under thirty feet of ash, left alone for some 1,700 years, until in the early 19th century some of the men wielding shovels found that their shoes sometimes broke through the crust into hollows below. Then archaeologists began to locate the holes and fill them with plaster. But that's neither here nor there. Without giving the matter much if any importance, I picked up scenes (or suggestions of scenes) from "Gladiator," "Spartacus," "Titanic," "The Horse Whisperer". and one or two others I've forgotten.In return for sitting through the formulaic events, you get in return a massive display of visual effects: flaming meteors, boulders falling from the sky, a giant tsunami, fires, earthquakes, landslides, a monstrous pyroclastic flow, and praising the chocolate cake at one of your own restaurants. It's such a shattering experience it will make you think twice. Twice but not three times.Informative datum. Pompeii had a red light district and the cobblestone street was worn down an inch or so by the heavy wagon traffic, like inverted railroad tracks.

Review title: Sword and Sandal spectacular with thrills , emotion , romance, breathtaking combats and overwhelming finale
Review_body: A Celt boy called Milo : Kim Harrington after the defeat his tribe is turned slave and taken as a gladiator . He is driven by misfortune to become an avenger gladiator fighting tremendous dangers and bouncing enemies .While governing Emperor Tito, Milo being transported in 79 A. D. to Pompeii when the eruption of the Vesuvius threatens noblemen and slaves alike . Milo finds himself in a race against time to save his true sweetheart , Cassia : Emily Browning, daughter of a wealthy family : Jared Harris , Carrie Anne Moss , and who has been unwillingly betrothed to a powerful Roman Senator : Kiefer Sutherland . Mt Vesuvius blows its top in fine fashion somewhere near the end of this Colossal film. No Warning . No escape . A City will Fall . A Hero will Rise .Some spectacular scenes , including the explosive climax when the mountain Vesuvius blows is top . State-of-art special effects look fantastic , including explosion , torrents of blazing lava and buildings destruction . This is an acceptable and passable Peplum , but all the molten lava the special effects team can cook up isn't enough for a cliché, dreary screenplay with some moments rather dumb. Attractive acting from duo starring , Kim Harrington as the revenger hero becomes a vengeful gladiator after tragedy takes his family and Emily Browning as his damsel in distress . But the acting honours go to Kiefer Sutherland as a memorable and extremely baddie Senator. Along with other notorious secondaries , such as : Adewale Agbaje as a kind gladiator , Sasha Roiz as nasty Proculus , Currie Graham as trainer Bellator , and Jared Harris , Carrie Anne Moss as parents . Displaying a moving and rousing musical score by Clinton Shorter . And equally a colorfully phototography by Glen MacPherson . The motion picture was professionally directed by Paul W. S. Anderson .This one is very freely based on Last Days Pompeii written by Lord Edward Lytton that has been previously adapted in 1935 by Ernest B Schoedsack with Preston Foster , Basil Rathbone , Alan Hale , Louis Calhern . The Last Days of Pompeii 1960 by Mario Bonnard , Sergio Leone with Steve Reeves , Christine Kaufmann, Angel Aranda , Mimmo Palmara . Pompeii 2007 by Giulio Base with Lorenzo Crespi , Maria Gracia Cucinotta .

Review title: Great effects film, but poor on storyline and characters...
Review_body: "Pompeii" is a rather dimwitted experience. The movie is sort of a mutant hybrid of "Gladiator" and "Volcano", and the end result is nowhere near as great as you would have initially hoped it would be.Let's break the story down, first there is the part that is basically a clone of "Gladiator", where the Romans kill Milo's family and entire people, and force the young boy into slavery, where he ends up becoming a gladiator with the might and ability to challenge the mightiest of Romans. Sure, cliché anyone? While this is essentially almost the same as "Gladiator", that part of the movie is actually good enough for what it is worth.Then a little over halfway through the movie, "Pompeii" takes a twist from being your average "Gladiator" clone and turns its heading towards a take on "Volcano". Again, this part of the movie actually is good, in fact it is the best part of the movie compared to the sappy "Gladiator" rip off.What makes "Pompeii" watchable is the effects that are brought to the screen during the natural disaster part of the movie. And they were great indeed, with the flooding, tsunami, exploding volcano, flaming meteoric rocks and pyroclastic cloud.As for the characters in the movie, well they were about as predictable and stereotypical as could be for a movie such as this. And you don't really invest anything into the characters, because they are wooden and one dimensional.The acting in the movie was adequate, given the limitations of the script and character development. But Kiefer Sutherland was really poorly cast for the role of Corvus. His acting is as forced, rigid and over-dramatic as that of Jeremy Irons, and it was like watching a parody of a Roman senator on the screen. Not the best move on the casting part.One of the better parts about "Pompeii" was the sets and wardrobe. The city of Pompeii looked really interesting and had a very realistic feel to it. But more impressively were the costumes, outfits and armors seen throughout the movie, especially that of the Roman legionnaires. I was blown away by their armors and gear.All in all, you know what you get here right from the very beginning, and there are no surprises or plot twists along the way, making "Pompeii" for a very streamlined and cruise-controlled movie experience. The ending to the movie, was at least better than if they had actually managed to outride the pyroclastic cloud."Pompeii" doesn't move any boundaries for the movie industry, nor does it bring about anything revolutionary or impressive. It is a mind dulling simplistic movie that is running on effects more than on storyline and characters.A mere 4 out of 10 stars from me.

Review title: Exciting Throwback of Spectacle and Bad Acting
Review_body: Entertaining and Exciting Guilty Pleasure of a Movie that Never Attempts to be Anything More than a Spectacle. It's All About the Volcano You See and You See it a lot. Everything Else is just Filler and Standard Sophomoric Romanticism and Hollywood History. But it Works.The Move has its Roots Firmly Planted in the B-Movie Matinée Fodder of the Fifties and Early Sixties. it Draws from the Sword and Sandal Bad Acting Imports and the Harryhausen Stop Motion Movies that were All Harryhausen and Little Else, OK Bernard Hermann.The Movie Looks Great and has Enormous Amounts of Action and some Violent Fight and Chase Scenes that Push the PG-13 Rating and when the Volcano Finally Blows its Top it is a CGI Bombardment that Blows the Mind. The Acting is Inconsequential and Mostly Mediocre to Bad and the Script is Non-Existent aside from Clichés. But who Cares?This isn't Shakespeare, Laurence Olivier, Russell Crowe, or even James Cameron. It's just a Movie that is Underrated and was a Big Flop, but is Recommended for Anyone that is a Kid at Heart and just Likes to Play and Never has Anything More on Their Mind.

Review title: Don't rush to judge - it's not great, but it is still quite entertaining...
Review_body: It's maybe apocryphal but there is a story of tourists visiting Windsor Castle and reportedly asking why they would build it under the Heathrow flightpath? Well this is a similar sort of affair - why would you build a town on the escapement of an active volcano? Well not only did they, but ambitious prospector "Severus" (Jared Harris) has aspirations to expand the town and so he and scheming wife "Aurelia" (Carrie-Anne Moss) try to worm their way into the good books of the visiting Senator "Corvus" (Kiefer Sutherland) who takes a bit of a shine to their young, independently minded daughter "Cassia" (Emily Browning) who has, herself, taken a bit of a shine to the bit of rough that is "Milo" (Kit Harrington). "Milo" is a slave destined to be a gladiator. He is skilful and shrewd, quickly befriends top dog prisoner "Atticus" (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje) and the scene is now set... Can he stay alive, save the girl from the clutches of the evil senator and escape the impeding volcano eruption? Well, what do you think? It's not the worst CGI-fest that you will ever watch, and the performances are adequate given the limited skills of the writers with some decent (3D) disaster effects towards the end that carry it along OK. Don't expect top notch drama, it's essentially a vehicle for Harrington to flex his pecs and for Sutherland to ham up his role as the Senator with loads of colourful pyrotechnics and absolutely no jeopardy whatsoever... Fun, though.

Review title: A Man, A Woman, and A Volcano
Review_body: "Resident Evil" director Paul W.S. Anderson must have loved both "Titanic" and "Gladiator" because "Pompeii" appropriates the template and tropes from those blockbusters. Nevertheless, "Pompeii" is not primarily a chick flick. "Game of Thrones" actor Kit Harington plays an enslaved warrior who lost his entire family when sadistic Romans slaughtered them in Britain. Harington is cast as the impoverished, but virtuous protagonist, while porcelain-faced Emily Browning plays Cassia, the pampered daughter of an affluent Pompeii entrepreneur. Cassia has had enough of Imperial Roman society and repellent Romans, specifically the wicked Senator Corvus (Kiefer Sutherland) who displays no qualms about killing not only the enemy but also his own if the mood strikes him. Aside from an invincible African-American gladiator (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje) already imprisoned at Pompeii, Anderson and his three scenarists confine themselves to this handful of characters, with a few loitering on the periphery. Indeed, characterization is kept to a demographic minimum. Not surprisingly, you'll sympathize with our tragic lovers while you'll abhor Corvus with a passion and applaud his comeuppance. If you've seen either "Titanic" or "Gladiator," you'll know what is going to happen to these characters before they do. "Batman Forever" co-scripters Janet Scott Batchler and Lee Batchler plus "Sherlock Holmes" scribe Michael Robert Johnson have recycled all the usual clichés. Anderson doesn't let anything interfere with the headlong momentum that he generates."Pompeii" unfolds in 62 AD in Britannia. A long-haired youngster, Milo (Dylan Schombing), escapes death from the swords of ruthless Roman soldiers. Corvus and his army annihilate Milo's tribe of Celtic horsemen. The Romans mistake young Milo for one of the dead and add his body to a pile of corpses. This is the familiar scene where the villains think our hero is dead, but really isn't dead. The last big-screen movie that used this trope was "The Lone Ranger." Nevertheless, the 'mistaken for dead' trope works dependably for "Pompeii." Eventually, after he proves his mettle on the battlefield as a superb horseman, Milo is enslaved. Years later, a Roman slave trader, Graecus (Joe Pingue) spots Milo, who has since acquired the moniker 'the Celt' for his fearless pugnacity. Milo is the equivalent of William Wallace in "Braveheart." Milo makes mincemeat out of all his adversaries. He winds up in Pompeii where he will clash swords with the undefeated champ, Atticus (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje of "Congo"), a bold combatant both agile and confident. Opposites through and through from pigment to pugnacity, these guys will have each other's back before the fat volcano sings.Our hero and heroine meet on the road to Pompeii. One of the horses drawing Cassia's carriage collapses. Milo intervenes despite the protest of his captor. As a member of the aristocracy, Cassia shields Milo from charges of insubordination for putting the horse out of its misery. She was on the way back from Rome where she had spent a year. Apparently, Cassia had a romantic relationship that ended awfully for both parties. Now, it is love at first sight when she sees Milo. The love that Milo feels for her will prompt him later to defy death. Meanwhile, Milo must battle lethal opponents in the arena. Eventually, Atticus and he become allies in the face of surely insurmountable odds. "Pompeii" boasts several exciting combat sequences, and the one in the arena against many Roman soldiers is reminiscent of something from his "Resident Evil" epics. Anderson orchestrates these close quarters combat scenes with agility and style. The actors parry and thrust in ways that bring out the ferocity and eloquence of the sword fights. Naturally, Cassia reacts with horror when Corvus demands she marry him or see her parents ruined. Jared Harris of "Sherlock Holmes: Game of Shadows" and Carrie Moss of "The Matrix" are relegated to secondary victim roles as Cassia's father Severus and mother Aurelia. Sadly, Moss models apparel without any gravity-defying martial arts moves."Pompeii" is predictable, but exciting nonsense. About an hour into the action, Mount Vesuvius erupts, and comparisons with "Dante's Peake" are inevitable. An alien attack couldn't be any more devastating than the multitude of fireballs catapulted from the combustible crucible of Vesuvius. Anderson and his CGI team have forged a spectacular fireworks show. The scenes of people scrambling chaotically to reach the Bay of Naples and the sanctuary of a ship at sea are exhilarating. As it turns out, even the ships aren't safe from these fireballs. During the third half-hour, our hero and heroine run desperately for their lives. Atticus is battling his adversaries in an effort to reach Milo, and Corvus is struggling to break through a mob of citizens who have him mired down in the streets. Simultaneously, Vesuvius unleashes one barrage of fireballs after another. Anderson really accelerates the action during the third half-hour.Surprisingly enough, at least to me, I enjoyed this Tristar Pictures release, but I have a soft spot for gladiator movies. "Pompeii" qualifies as more of an actioneer than a chick flick. Notably, our lovers are young, but they never consummate their soulful relationship which makes their love all the more chaste. The slam-bang ending that audiences may not buy because things end tragically is probably the strongest thing about "Pompeii." Mind you, Anderson has made a gripping little sword and sandal saga with a love story to sweeten up the shenanigans. The heroes are virtuous; the villains are vicious; and the wrath of Mother Nature is vast in its fury. Mount Vesuvius grumbles ominously in the background until it explodes and earthquakes rock the city. Clocking in at a Spartan 98-minutes,"Pompeii" never wears out its welcome, and its breathtaking CGI reenactment of Mount Vesuvius blowing its stack is lavishly larger-than-life. Naturally, the CGI imagery here surpasses anything three earlier movies, such as the 1913 silent version as well as the 1935 as well as 19959 versions of "The Last Days of Pompeii," offered.Altogether, despite its tragic finale, "Pompeii" will keep you captivated with its volcanic pyrotechnics and its gladiatorial conflicts.

Titanic happens, there's a volcano for a little bit, roll credits. No, really. To flesh that out, slave/horse whisperer(!) Milo(Harington, with at most one emotion on his face during this) falls for Cassia(Browning, the closest of anyone to come out of this with dignity intact, her role defined by something) and vice versa. Thankfully we're told this, because they don't sell you on it at all. She's marrying senator PalpatineI mean, Corvus(Sutherland, Jack Bauer with a strange British accent). And there's an eruption(well see above), which represents the only arresting visual and composition(if you do subject yourself to this, definitely go for 3D, it is immersive, with fantastic depth and rare use of gimmicks). At no point does this give us a reason to care(or stay awake, other than the rubbernecking at a car crash kind of thing), have more than one or two inspired moments that aren't lazily lifted from a much better film(Spartacus and 300 added to the notable ones)or have anything going for it other than great production values.I am in awe of Paul W.S. Anderson. He must draw an audience, he keeps being given a budget(and it shows), and he continues to waste tremendous talent in front of the camera, and he still gets work. This does make more sense than other recent works by him, presumably he's charging up for the next burst, saving it for yet another wrong-from-the-word-go Resident Evil movie, fuelled by the salty tears of fans. There's less slow-mo, and this certainly is the first time that he could not choose between two genres so he combined them, so there's that. Yeah, a gladiator piece and a disaster flick, neither of them compelling. Of course, he still has build-up not match pay-off(too much of one for the other, in both ways), for easing up on Alien, he refuses to leave Ridley Scott's films alone and "kill your darlings" is a foreign concept to him. No real fun is had, nothing goes anywhere and hardly anything in this will stick with you –we're talking, maybe a handful a full 60 seconds out of the seemingly insurmountable 97 minute running time.There's a lot of violence and disturbing content in this, particularly awful for how distinctly it's neutered to be a PG-13. I recommend this solely to anyone else compelled to gawk at the trainwreck that can be attributed entirely to the substantial incompetence of its conductor. 7/10

Review title: A bad film, but entertainingly so
Review_body: Evil Roman Senator Kiefer Sutherland, overdosing on ham, wipes out an entire tribe of British horse whisperers except for a small boy who grows up to be someone I've never heard of playing a character called Milo. Milo gets sent to be a gladiator in Pompeii, where he impresses rich girl Emily Browning by killing her horse. Imagine his surprise when evil Senator Kiefer Sutherland turns up to do evil things. Imagine everyone's surprise when Vesuvius decides to have a bit of a coughing fit.There is an excellent novel called Pompeii by respected author Robert Harris in which the lead up to the 79AD eruption is told through the problems faced by an engineer tasked with solving the problem of why the Pompeii aqueduct has gone dry. Sadly, this film is not based on that book. Instead we get a load of sub-Gladiator nonsense leading up to the admittedly well-realised eruption which, after all, is the real reason for this film to exist.This film is full of bad points - the "story" is pretty rubbish, the two leads are completely forgettable (and Emily Browning looks weirder than usual), much of what happens is just plain stupid (a 4-horse chariot through the ruined streets of a town which is being smashed to pieces by a volcano?), Jared Harris and Carrie-Anne Moss put in what amount to pointless cameos, and Kiefer Sutherland overacts enough for any five other actors - if the Romans had pantomime villain moustachios, Sutherland would have twirled his constantly while uttering "Mwah hah ha!".But the film has what, to me, were two saving graces. One is that same Kiefer Sutherland performance. It is one of those examples of bad acting which is so over the top as to be entertaining - think Alan Rickman in Robin Hood, Prince Of Thieves. And the other is the eruption itself. Oh, and kudos for killing everyone, including the two romantic leads - I like that, even if it does bankrupt any emotional investment you may have made in what comes before.This is a bad film but, for me, it was one of those bad films where the bad is entertaining.The 3D was very poor.

With a poll being held on IMDbs Classic Film board for the best titles of 2014,I started to make plans on catching up on Bollywood movies from the year.As I got nearer to watching the Bollywoods,I began to hear a surprising amount of praise from fellow IMDbers and a family friend over a sword & scandals epic which had suffered a painful death at the box office,which led to me getting ready to pay a visit to Pompeii.The plot:After his family are slaughtered in front of his young eyes by Senator Quintas Attius Corvus,Milo is taken as a slave,who is trained to become a gladiator by his slave owner.Decades later:Having made his name as the most successful gladiator, Atticus is told by his owner,that after he wins his next match,he will finally be freed from slavery.Suspecting Atticus's final match to be a big draw,the slave owner decides to put Atticus against a young up & comer,who the crowd have nicknamed "the Celt",but is known by his slave owner as Milo.Walking with his fellow slaves from Rome to Pompeii,Milo has to kill a horse,after it fails whilst pulling a carriage containing the rulers of Pompeii.Killing the horse in the most humane way possible,Pompeii ruler Cassia is taken by the kindness that Milo shows towards the horse.Determined to finally be free,Atticus ignores Milo's hand of friendship.and sets his sights on freedom.Catching his fiancé Cassia starring at Milo for a little too long, Senator Quintas Attius Corvus decides that he must show his iron fist,as he sets his sights on a power-grab of Pompeii.Getting set to face each other one on one,Atticus & Milo suddenly find their owner to turn on them,as they are chucked into a to the death battle royal,which Corvus hopes will kill Milo,and any threat of an uprising taking place.View on the film:Keeping the film moving at a frantic 104 minute running time, (with the studio trimming 20 minutes out of the title)the screenplay by Janet Scott Batchler, Lee Batchler and Michael Robert Johnson unleashes a superb mix of Disaster movie thrills and sweetly done light romantic notes.Whilst Corvus's focus on destroying Milo as Pompeii burns does look a bit petty, (even though we are all about to die,I MUST kill you now!)the writers smartly decide to keep everything down to earth,with the destruction of Pompeii being based around the torn love of Milo & Cassia,rather than a hollow smash and grab destruction.Opening and closing the film with a breath-taking wraparound shot, (which is actually based on a stature in the ruins of Pompeii)director Paul W.S. Anderson and cinematographer Glen MacPherson keeps the action building,at a gradual,devastating pace,as terror waiting to face Pompeii rumbles in the background,whilst Milo & Atticus fight for survival in sharp,tough as Odin fight scenes.Making sure that the stunning action never overwhelms the flick,Anderson and Macpherson give the title an elegant acrylic appearance,which covers the film in a near fairy- tale atmosphere,as Milo and Cassia's romance rises from Pompeii's ashes.For the unlucky souls of Pompeii,the movie offers the tantalising chance to see the leads of 24,The Matrix and a double bill of HBO's Oz and Game of Thrones battle for survival in Pompeii.Giving the character a sense of depth not featured in the screenplay, Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje gives a touching performance as Atticus,with Agbaje melting the characters stony heart to reveal Atticus's burning desire to get revenge on his slave owners,and the rulers of Pompeii.Despite his voice surprisingly lacking his distinctive twang, Kiefer Sutherland gives a wicked performance as Corvus,thanks to Sutherland showing a burning insanity in Corvus eyes,as he sets his sights on putting the gladiators back in their place.Whilst he appears surprisingly nervous in the CGI-focused scenes, Kit Harington gives a very good performance as Milo,with Harington slowly turning Milo's fiery thrust for vengeance against Corvus,into a fiery passion for Cassia,as they both watch Pompeii burn.Final view on the film:Two thumbs up!!

Review title: The Titanic Gladiator meets Frankie Howard......
Review_body: Milo is a slave, who witnessed His family killed by Jack Bauer of all people, when he was just a little nipper.Years later, he is a gladiator, a very good one, who spends his time smouldering when he isn't fighting.In the way to the titular place, he puts a horse out of its misery, and this causes Emily Browning to fall for him.Then there's all this cobblers about Bauer having to marry Browning, because he is just so darn despicable, just like Billy Zane in Titanic, but guess what? Browning only has eyes for Milo.And the big twist? The iceberg is now a volcano, and their love for each other is going to erupt.....Well it's a load of old rubbish really, Sutherland is terrible as the bad guy, but he is funny, in a really 'you know what to expect sort of way'.And this is why the film entertains so much, you know what to expect. It's by Anderson who gave us Mortal Kombat, Shopping, AvP, and the Resident Evil Franchise, so if you expect something epic, watch The Towering Inferno.The film is unintentionally hilarious, from the shaking of the city every five minutes, and people saying 'oh it's alright, it does this all the time', to the final third, which in all fairness, is very impressive.We get Milo chasing Sutherland, who has Browning, and it plays out almost like the end bit of the Wacky Races, who's going to make?And Anderson must have thought there was only one road out of there, because everyone, literally everyone, goes down the same path.If you want to switch your brain off from the world, for 100 minutes, and just want a silly popcorn movie with great effects, welcome to Pompeii.If you expect something great, and marvellous, you are clearly deluded.Good for all the wrong reasons...

Review title: Destruction scenes deliver but the story is ludicrous
Review_body: The destruction of Pompeii with all the fiery rocks plummeting down on the city is stunning and as far as special effects go it doesn't look overdone. The recreation of the city is picture perfect. The story unfortunately is clichéd and takes up too much of the movie absurdly intruding into the destruction part. I know they had to have some back story. A Celtic gladiator falls in love with noble lady and seeks revenge on evil Roman soldier who wants to marry the same lady. The fighting is endless, ridiculously continuing post eruption.The casting is hit and miss. Kit Harington (Game of Thrones) plays the gladiator and he is convincing enough. Emily Browning (Sucker Punch) is the lady. They make a cute couple but the role might have been better filled by some one more classically beautiful. Her mother is played by Carrie Anne Moss (Matrix) who is looks like a lady from a Pompeiian fresco and is the best cast looks wise. Kiefer Sutherland is just wrong as the villain who can't let go.Although the ending is poignant in a way, it felt like all the struggle and fighting was for nothing.Overall watch this for the destruction which is the most spectacular so far of any Pompeii movie or series. Just be warned the story is bad.

Review title: Delivers the goods as a quality sword & sandal/disaster flick
Review_body: Released in 2014 and directed by Paul Anderson, "Pompeii" details the destruction of the titular Italian city and surrounding villages in 79 AD; the remains of the area was buried under 13-20 feet of volcanic ash & pumice from the eruption of nearby Mount Vesuvius. Kit Harington stars as Celtic slave, Milo, brought to Pompeii; Emily Browning stars as his potential romantic interest, Cassia, a princess of the city. Carrie-Anne Moss and Jared Harris are on hand as her parents while Kiefer Sutherland plays an arrogant Roman Senator, Corvus, the villain of the pic. Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje stands out as a champion gladiator and Milo's cellmate while Jessica Lucas has a peripheral role as Cassia's best friend.The tone is akin to 2000's "Gladiator" but with pretty-boy Harington rather than seasoned he-man Crowe. Of course the other big difference is that this is part disaster flick; and it delivers spectacularly on this front in the final act. In any case, "Pompeii" has a more compelling story and better characters, cartoony though they may be. "Gladiator" took the more low-key route, but I always found it semi-boring, although I still like it (not love it). Browning shines as the princess while Adewale practically steals the show. Some may scoff at the ending as unrealistic, but it likely happened in some cases. After all, if you KNOW you're doomed anyway why not? I found it almost profound. The friendship that develops between two of the characters is similarly well-done.The film runs 105 minutes and was shot at Cinespace Film Studios, Toronto, with exteriors done at Pompeii, Naples, Campania, Italy. The movie cost a whopping $80 million and 'only' made back $118 million worldwide, with $23 million taken in the USA. As such, it was considered a flop. But it's NOT a failure as a sword & sandal flick and stands well with similar films like 2004's "Troy." GRADE: A-/B+

Pompeii is a historical formulated genre. Pompeii has a Romance/love triangle with Kit Harrington as the underdog, hero, and gladiator. Emily Browning plays the girl in distress. It was nice to see Kit Harrington in something other than the Game of Thrones. Is he going to be a typed casted actor with only action roles? Kiefer Sutherland portrays the Roman senator/ villain who will be unscrupulous and nasty. The gladiator/action genre with many sword fights and villains fighting heroes. The volcano is the disaster part with earthquakes, fire balls, smokes, etc. Well acted, directed, with the right mix of the three genres. Entertaining, but no American Hustle. Six out of ten fire balls.

With "Gladiator" and "Troy", the early years of the twenty-first century saw a revival of the classical epic, a film genre previously believed to have become extinct in the mid-sixties. The critical and commercial failure of Oliver Stone's "Alexander" meant that this revival was shot- lived, but with "Noah" and "Pompeii" and a film about the legend of Hercules to come, 2014 seems to be the year that sees a revival of the revival. The eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD is one of the best-known natural disasters in history, due mainly to the eye-witness account of the Roman writer Pliny the Younger and to the once-famous novel "The Last Days of Pompeii" by Edward Bulwer-Lytton. The plot of "Pompeii" is essentially that of "Titanic", another film based upon a famous historical disaster, with a volcano standing in for the iceberg. Poor boy loves posh girl, who is also loved (or at least lusted after) by a rich upper-class bastard. Can poor boy and posh girl escape when disaster strikes? The Jack Dawson figure here is Milo, a Celtic slave from Britain forced to fight as a gladiator. (And what Roman epic would be complete without gladiators? Well, perhaps "Ben-Hur", but then that film featured the equally exciting sport of chariot racing). Milo's bit of posh is Cassia, the daughter of a wealthy Pompeian businessman, and the upper-class bastard is Corvus, a corrupt and arrogant Roman Senator. Quite apart from their rivalry over Cassia, Milo has good reason to hate Corvus. Seventeen years earlier, when Milo was a young boy, Corvus was the commander of the Roman army which wiped out his tribe, killed his parents and captured him and sold him into slavery. In a nod to the greatest gladiator film of all, Stanley Kubrick's "Spartacus", Milo is befriended by a black fellow-gladiator.The above synopsis might suggest that "Pompeii" also incorporates a "Romeo and Juliet"-style story about young lovers drawn from two hostile camps, but the scriptwriters seemed so keen to make all Romans into the villains that they insist that Cassia and her family are not Romans at all but "Pompeians", a quite separate ethnic group living unwillingly under the Roman yoke. The historical accuracy of this is doubtful; by 79AD distinctions between the Romans and the Samnites, their Oscan- speaking rivals who had at one time inhabited this area of Southern Italy, had become blurred- all the graffiti found in Pompeii are in Latin rather than Oscan- and there is no evidence of opposition to Roman rule from this period. The script is often hackneyed and clichéd and the acting tends to be serviceable rather than distinguished, with the one exception of Kiefer Sutherland, who is lip-smackingly odious as the villainous Corvus, although I should perhaps point out that Kit Harington and Emily Browning, who play the two young lovers, are better than Leonardo di Caprio and Kate Winslet were when playing the equivalent roles in "Titanic"- and look what heights Leo and Kate have gone on to since 1997. This is, however, a film where the real stars are not the actors but the fight arrangers and the special effects people. The gladiatorial combats are as exciting as those in any previous epic, including "Spartacus" and "Gladiator" itself, but even they are outshone by the marvellous scenes of the eruption itself. Granted, these scenes are not always justified by historical accounts of the eruption itself- the eruption was not accompanied by a tsunami as shown here and Pompeii was not subjected to bombardment by fireballs- but that does not detract from their raw, heart-stopping emotional power. This is one of those rare occasions where I feel that the special effects justify a higher mark than I would otherwise have given. 8/10

Review title: It's "Titanic" Set In The Roman Empire
Review_body: Almost from beginning to end I was having feelings of deja vu while I watched this. Think about the story. There's a disaster a-comin'. We know that. There's no mystery about it. Pretty much everyone knows the story of Pompeii being destroyed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius. The story of Pompeii's last days gets told through a romance that brings together boy and girl from different classes. In this case it's the slave turned gladiator Milo (Kit Harington) and Aurelia, the daughter of Pompeii's leading citizen (Carrie-Ann Moss) who ignore their difference in social status and fall for each other. One problem, though, is that she has a powerful man who she doesn't like but who expects to marry her in her life (Sen. Corvus, played by Kiefer Sutherland.) Wait a minute. Basically, that's the plot of 1997's "Titanic" transplanted to ancient Rome. OK. It loses on the originality scale."Pompeii" has some strengths. The sets work, and it seems to be a reasonable portrayal of ancient Rome. The special effects around the eruption of Vesuvius are well done. There's even an interesting and still relevant political reflection about the opposition to centralized government. The movie opens with a rebellion against Roman rule by Celtic tribes in Britain, and even though Pompeii is a stone's throw from Rome, you get the impression that its citizens are less then enamoured with the Empire's capital. And this is mercifully short. Most blockbusters these days (and my sense is that this was intended to be a blockbuster) seem to feel the need to be stretched out to at least three hours. This comes in at less than two.The length, mind you, demonstrates the movie's biggest weakness: a weak story. It plods along, it's not especially exciting, and the romance didn't draw me in. I didn't much care about these two - or anyone else. That's a huge weakness. I'd frankly rather just watch "Titanic" again. (5/10)

Review title: Like a mixture of 'GLADIATOR', 'SPARTACUS: WAR OF THE DAMMED' and 'TITANIC'!
Review_body: 'POMPEII': Three and a Half Stars (Out of Five)Director Paul W.S. Anderson's new $100 million flick is a 'sword-and-sandal' romantic disaster film. It's loosely based on history and set during the destruction of an ancient Roman town (Pompeii) in 79 A.D. Britannia. The movie stars Kit Harington (of 'GAME OF THRONES' fame), Emily Browning, Kiefer Sutherland, Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje, Carrie-Anne Moss and Jared Harris and was written by Janet Scott Batchler and Lee Batchler (who also co-wrote 'BATMAN FOREVER') as well as Michael Robert Johnson. It's definitely not high quality entertainment but unless you're a really big film snob (or just hate the genre) you should probably find it (at least mildly) amusing.Harington plays Milo, a slave-turned-gladiator who witnessed his mother and entire people (a tribe of Celtic horsemen) murdered by Corvus (Sutherland), and his Roman army, when he was just a young boy (Dylan Schombing). 17 years later he's boughten by the slave owner Graecus (Joe Pingue), for his gladiator skills, and taken to Pompeii with other slaves. He meets Cassia (Browning), along the way, while putting her fallen horse out of it's misery. They're immediately drawn to each other but their love is forbidden as Cassia is the daughter of Severus (Harris) and Aurelia (Moss), the city rulers. She's also the object of Corvus's affection, who is now a Senator visiting Pompeii. Milo (known only as 'the Celt') is to do battle with a champion gladiator named Atticus (Akinnuoye-Agbaje), who is seeking his freedom (through what is supposed to be his final fight), all for the amusement of Corvus. Things become more complicated when the volcano, Mount Vesuvius, erupts.The movie, like almost all of Anderson's films (who should never be confused with the great Paul Thomas Anderson), is what I'd consider a guilty pleasure. I found it to be pretty cheesy but highly entertaining. It looks great, the effects are cool and the action scenes are amusing. The acting is decent enough and the characters are mostly, at least somewhat, likable (especially Atticus). It does feel like a mixture of a lot of other popular films and TV shows (like 'GLADIATOR', 'SPARTACUS: WAR OF THE DAMMED' and 'TITANIC') but that's what is kind of fun about it. A 'B movie' at it's most grand!Watch our movie review show 'MOVIE TALK' at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x-G3-O3wYgs

Paul W. S. Anderson's "Pompeii" is a throwback to all those sword-and-sandal epics of yesteryear that combined period-piece spectacle with generous dollops of bloodletting, action and romance. This 1st Century soap opera just happens to take place in the shadow of Vesuvius, the volcano that famously erupted in 79 A.D., burying much of the city and its inhabitants in tombs of molten rock and ash.Looking like he barely needed a change of wardrobe from his day job, "Game of Throne's" Kit Harrington plays Milo, a Celtic boy who, after he witnesses his family being slaughtered by Roman troops in the northernmost region of the empire, is forced into slavery and raised to become a gladiator. When he's brought to Pompeii to fight in the arena, he catches the eye of Cassia (Emily Browning), a thoroughly anachronistic, sassy, forward-looking, freethinking type who finds the officials in Rome to be all uncouth barbarians and who has no taste for such popular blood-soaked pastimes as fight-to-the-death battles in the coliseum. A ludicrously miscast Keifer Sutherland plays a foul Roman senator who tries to come between the noble woman and the slave.As befits the genre, "Pompeii" is just chockablock with stock characters, cheesy dialogue and corny plotting, though the movie does earn a few points for its unlikely and, dare I say it, even quite brave finale.But, of course, anyone who checks out "Pompeii" will be doing so strictly to witness, albeit vicariously, all the death and destruction visited upon the city and its thousands of inhabitants when Vesuvius finally blows its top. Apparently, overproduced, CGI-infested disaster movies are our milder, modern-day equivalent to gladiatorial contests. And in that respect, at least, the movie delivers the goods.There's one thing that "Pompeii," fortunately, doesn't have in common with those toga-wrapped spectacles of the past - and that is their extraordinary length. So clocking in at a relatively brief 104 minutes, "Pompeii" has at least one thing going for it.

I always think this movie, Pompeii, looks like a sequel due to the final two letters and in a sense, it might as well be one to Pearl Harbor. Heck, they even mention a harbor a ton in the climax.And much like that terrible Michael Bay WWII injustice, this movie is only good for one scene. Can't hardly spoil this by saying it ends with the volcano erupting, and that's the only thing worth watching in this terrible, no good film. Unfortunately, that's barely worth it due to the characters and their incredibly bad decisions during the disaster.I'm not just talking about people panicking and making poor choices. That's easy and forgiven as we've proved to be idiots in disasters. I'm talking about the spilled over drama, politics and macho-macho men. The moment there's a break in the carnage, the "characters" do so many dumb and clichéd things, the spectacle we all came for was diverted to the D- Class level of the Titanic. Backing up, the poor excuse for a story revolves around a slave/gladiator who loves a fair lady, and there's trouble with the politicians, etc, whatever. Look. I just watched this and barely remember the first hour of this tired and warn-out concept. I understand the movie might not have worked as just the volcano erupting, but the opening scenes of Superman: The Movie and its pending doom of Krypton were far more interesting than the first hour here.In fact, if you must see this, just skip the first hour all together. The volcano's massive attack was pretty good if you can just ignore the main character's dumb fighting. I just wish I could rate this higher for the FX alone, but the rest of the movie – even with some fine and beautiful actors – was so bad, it's hard to even recommend the climatic world's end disaster. Fine. A slight recommendation to just begin the movie at the end of hour 1. DangI am so glad I didn't see this in theatres or I would've hated life for those initial 60 minutes.***Final thoughts: which is what I did for the equally dreadful Pearl Harbor. I *did* see that in theatres, hated life the first hour and a half to get to the title fight and then actually wanted to end my life for the horrific remaining, completely unnecessary additional hour. Man, that movie would never end. Mercifully, this movie wasn't too long, but I was really let down we didn't get to see the aftermath of the volcano or even have the stereotypical, albeit welcomed, end screen notes on: how many died, what happened next, etc., etc. It was really the only cliché they didn't use and it would've been the most welcomed one. Shame.

Had some questionable parts but had enough awesomeness to cancel it out. loved all the parts with the volcano and the gladiators. perfect ending and a good love story with good action and awesome scenes (2 viewings)

Review title: Should be awful but it works...for the most part
Review_body: I will make one thing explicitly clear about Pompeii, you CAN really enjoy yourself but you have to turn your brain off, sit back, get your popcorn ready and just have fun. Yes, its one of those movies. It isn't Gladiator, it isn't Titanic...its crazy, sappy, cheesy fun. My expectations for this were extremely high though the horde of bad reviews probably brought them down to a slightly more reasonable level. I kept trying to go see this and for one reason or another didn't get to so I was pretty excited to finally catch it on its last night at the local theatre. I didn't see it in 3D which is fine by me because 99.9% of the time I find this new 3D fad a complete waste though I can see in this film where they certainly made it a point to make sure it was 3D capable. As many other reviews have said, the film is a blend of ancient Roman gladiators and a disaster flick. Anyone who knows even the slightest bit of this story knows how its going to turn out. The story is decent, certainly entertaining enough, but so many of the characters and performances are downright cheesy. Fortunately sometimes campy can win you over and in this case I ended up enjoy it despite those performances or because of them in at least one case which I will mention shortly.Kit Harington is a relative newcomer and someone I wasn't familiar with. The work he put into his physical performance cannot go unnoticed because he looks incredible and his body is ripped. Fortunately for him he actually turns in a pretty darn good performance too as our hero. The character in many ways is almost a carbon copy of Russell Crowe's hero in Gladiator but Harington pulls it off and keeps your attention and I don't think this film will do much for his career but I think we will see him in something big eventually. Emily Browning also gives a pretty solid performance as the girl that falls in love with him. Their romance is a little rushed and very Titanic-esque but it isn't too rushed and makes sense and their chemistry is very good. Its not epic but it works. This is actually one of the better performances I've seen from Browning, especially lately. Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje seems to be the one thing from this film that comes out unscathed by poor reviews and for good reason. He is mesmerizing and fantastic as slave-champion Atticus. In fact, this would have been a whole different level of film had he been the star. He absolutely steals every scene and is literally magnificent in an otherwise "okay" movie. The relationship between him and Harington drives this story to new heights. I adore Kiefer Sutherland and was excited that he was in this. He is the aforementioned "terrible" performance that I loved. He is beyond campy in this. His fake (and poor British accent) and he just looks awkward and out of place and yet he was an astoundingly evil villain. It was like a cartoon villain but a great one complete with one-liners and truly evil like glaring and cackling. He would have made an awesome 80's action villain. The rest of the cast were mostly filler and some did better than others. Jared Harris was good in a small role as Browning's protective father whereas Carrie-Anne Moss was atrocious as her mother in a thankfully small role.I am a big fan of the Resident Evil Series and there is no doubt that Paul WS Anderson loves to balance spectacular special effects and tons of action with a decent story. Some of his films are truly top notch in my books (The Three Musketeers, Resident Evil, Event Horizon.) It seems sometimes he focuses too much on the special effects and Pompeii is partly one of those projects. Some of the CGI is poor at best. Some IMDb reviewers rave about the Volcanic eruption scenes looked cartoony to me (perhaps because they were meant to be in 3D.) However, there are some strong scenes of CGI too. The build up in the film is to the apocalyptic eruption so I found myself waiting anxiously for it to happen and when it does, its a little bit of a letdown. Still I realized walking out of the film that I enjoyed myself. It was a little bit of mindless fun and certainly not meant to be a historical epic. I will watch it again and enjoy it for what it is. It won't change historical epics but have some fun! 7.5/10

A little known fact is that, two thousand years ago, everything was computer generated. In ancient Rome computer generated people lived in computer generated buildings in computer generated cities set against computer generated back-drops. Or at least they did until computer generated disasters befell them.Or at least it seemed that way if you've just watched Pompeii. Wow, there's a lot of CGI in that film. But then that's the least if it's faults. I could have lived with the amount of computer generated sets if it wasn't for the fact that everything going on in front of it has been done to death a million times.Someone else described it as 'Titanic meets Gladiator.' If only, but I can sort of see where they're coming from. It's a completely factually inaccurate account of a British native (I call him 'Jon Snow' as I only know his 'Game of Thrones' character and he's basically the same surly loner) whose parents are killed by the (typically horrible) Romans and he's taken away to be trained as a gladiator for their savage amusement. On his way he just so happens to meet the one rich princess who falls instantly in love with him within ten seconds of their encounter. The only trouble is she's only bequeathed to the evil Roman senator responsible for poor ol' Jon Snow's family's demise.I found it quite hard to believe that, after all this time, that plot line is still being used. It comes across like a Disney film with live actors (and much CGI scenery). It's not the actors' fault – they've hardly been given an Oscar-worthy script to work with. The plot is predictable and the dialogue just about passable.But you're probably not watching it for its deep and meaningful plot line – you just want to see things explode. And they do. But only really in the last twenty minutes. As in all the old accounts, Pompeii gets sacked and everything gets blown up, albeit here computers do the job of the real volcano etc. It's not that inspiring. If you're really looking for destruction, watch the Avengers or any other big budget film where a city gets destroyed in a PG sort of setting, meaning you hardly see any real death and destruction.However, despite Pompeii's many flaws (and I haven't even touched n Kiefer Sutherland's weird accent), it's not that bad. It's a film to watch and remove your brain. Just sit there and eat popcorn. If you're expecting something amazing then you're always going to be let-down. It's an average film, but if you set your sights low enough then you'll probably stay entertained for nearly two CGI hours.

Review title: a film made 50 years too late
Review_body: I saw 'Pompeii' in the wrong place and at the wrong time. Movies that heavily advertise their 3D effects must be seen in cinemas equipped with this projection technology. I skipped the movie at its time in cinemas, and I just saw it now at home, in reasonable conditions, but not in 3D, so I lost the thrill caused by the lava waves and fire boulders threatening my body integrity. The story of the film is of course a disaster that is famous from the history books, while the story that was crafted on it is kind of typical for the historical mega-productions at the mid-20th century, plus some melodrama a la 'Titanic'. Too late and too conventional for the second decade of the 21st century. Yet, the catastrophe remains on the screen, the film itself is not a disaster, rather like at the limit of acceptable entertainment.Almost everything that's happening in this movie prepares the special effects of the last 30 minutes. The story is a kind of simpler 'Gladiator' that includes a love story between a Celt slave (played by Kit Harington) and a noble Roman girl (played by Emily Browning) that has just as much chances of being consumed as the people of Pompeii had to escape the disaster. Film director Paul W.S. Anderson fails to infuse too much life into this pretext-story, and focuses on rendering on screen bloody gladiator fights and the special effects of the volcano. These are really well-directed, the realism of the men's confrontations in the arena and outside it being basically the only, let us say, modern features of the film.The actors' performances are acceptable. Besides the two actors in the main roles, the cast also includes Kiefer Sutherland, an actor I like to watch in any movie or TV series where he appears. The special effects are of good quality. Viewers looking for art movies have nothing to find in this film. Spectators who are looking for acceptable entertainment and who properly calibrate their expectations are likely to have a good time watching this movie.

Review title: a stero-typical romance set in the destruction of Pompeii
Review_body: First, Kit Harington is a rather petite fellow, to be playing a kick @ss gladiator. The casting was not good. And why did it seem like everyone was trying to pull off an English accent. That was the silliest part of all. But get past these major blemishes and you have a typical Hollywood romance.Milo's parents are killed by the evil Romans and he becomes a slave. He wins his way to Rome because he can easily kill gladiators 3 times his size. Then he's transferred to Pompeii and catches the eye of the Lady Cassia because he kills a horse. Keifer Sutherland plays the evil Roman senator whom still is mean after the volcano erupts. Of course Keifer uses evil tactics to get the hand of Cassia but before he take off with her, the volcano erupts. So you have the escaped gladiators, including Milo, whom must save Cassia before going to the harbor. But the harbor, gets wiped out but Milo still has Keifer to deal with. No one seems to care that lava and explosions are just happening everywhere. It's like I'm a Roman and you're a slave so we must fight.FINAL VERDICT: Silly accents, special effects, over the top love story, bad casting. It's one of those movies that people love because it's so bad. I say check it out, it makes for great background noise.

Now I've heard all the nasty things said about Paul Anderson, but I cannot vouch those statements because I have not seen many of his films to this point, perhaps purposely though. I do know that he crafted a beautiful-looking disaster film that is much better than I thought it would be. Maybe because I hold a soft spot for these kind of films, but this is an entertaining film with great visuals, a good score, and great acting. The script could be a little better, but of course I'm not expecting this film to be Gladiator or Armageddon. Paul Anderson's film is an epic tragic love story set amongst the impending doom of the massive volcanic eruption of Pompeii in A.D 79. Milo is a former slave turned gladiator who fights for his true love, Cassia while trying to keep her from the clutches of the wicked Roman senator, Quintus Corvus. The acting is pretty good, which added more dimensions to each character. Kit Harington is a macho man to be sure, but he has more substance than I expected thus making him a fine leading man. Emily Browning is all grown up now as Cassia. Admittedly, Kiefer Sutherland's performance is sort of hammy, but in a good way. I did think Carrie-Ann Moss and Jared Harris were good in their limited roles. Overall, Pompeii is a better-than-average disaster film. The visuals are excellent and the eruption of Mount Vesuvius is quite breath-taking. There are minor flaws, mostly surrounding the story as there were some few things that could be taken away or used some explaining. But I liked the premise. Sure the film is no Gladiator, but it is entertaining in its own way. My Grade: B+

Review title: Worth watching if you want to see stuff blow up & people fight. That said it's pretty entertaining & I'm glad I watched it.
Review_body: "Some prayed for help. Many wished for death. But in the city forever lost, the greatest secret still waits" Milo (Harington) was just a boy when his parents were killed in a raid on his city and sold into slavery. While on his way to the city of Pompeii to take part in gladiator fights he sees and instantly falls in love with Cassia (Browning), a wealthy merchants daughter. She feels the same about him but they must hide their feelings. What starts off as a gladiator fight for survival against other warriors becomes a fight against mother nature when the mighty volcano blows. He will stop at nothing to find a way to escape the city with Cassia. I have to admit I was not looking forward to seeing this at all. I am not a big fan of gladiator movies at all. I don't know why but I have never found them interesting. That said I did like the movie much more then I expected to. The movie in a way is like Pearl Harbor to me. The first half is a cookie cutter love story and the second half is one long action sequence. I will admit that the eruption effects were really neat, especially in 3D but for better or worse that's what the movie should really be seen for. Even though it's nothing amazing it was much better then I heard and I expected. Overall, a movie worth watching if you want to see stuff blow up and people fight. That said it is pretty entertaining and I'm glad I watched it. I give this a B.

PompeiiThe best part about living next to a volcano is that it doubles as a garbage incinerator.Unfortunately, it looks as though the civilization in this disaster movie have overextended theirs. Brought to the great city as a slave turned gladiator, Milo (Kit Harington) makes a name for himself when he comes to the assistance of Cassia (Emily Browning), the daughter of Pompeii's ruler (Jared Harris).In the area Milo must face Atticus (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje), a warrior with only one more fight to win his freedom.Observing the match is the Roman Senator (Kiefer Sutherland) who murdered Milo's mother years earlier.When Mount Vesuvius erupts, Milo gets his chance at revenge and love.Disrespecting the many lives lost in AD 79, this Paul W. S. Anderson effects laden epic earns points for the devastation but not for the simplistic delivery.And to think, it could've all been avoid with more virgin sacrifices. Red Lightvidiotreviews.blogspot.ca

Review title: Outside of some effects - just bad.
Review_body: Dialogue & acting - repackaged as old English (18th century) by Hollywood for it's lyrical movieness (and to fit Hollywood stereotyping). Acting was daytime soap TV level. Characters - noncreative, plug and play characters e.g. gladiators (one black & soon to become friends with adversary - been done before); other gladiator sees parents die at Roman hands and is now old enough for revenge - also been done before; really bad Romans acting badly; aristocratic pretty daughter (still has 21st century make up, eye liner, etc.) falls for slave gladiator (of course). Action scenes - good gladiators defeat dozens of Romans as brunch (I was waiting for one hand tied behind the back and blindfolded but the writers copped out). CGI - flashes of CGI volcano every 5 to 10 minutes to remind us of what the movie is about. Familiar scenes of water rushing over the city - already used in many tsunami movies and is getting old. Looked like the same wave used in several Indian Ocean tsunami films recently, but not as well done as say in "The Impossible". Fireballs came off as comical fireworks effects.

Review title: Fans erupt, Pompeii is buried. It was a disaster movie, alright. It wasn't that good, but not the worst. It's watchable.
Review_body: Pompeii had everything going for it. It was a great concept that hasn't been used for years. Sadly, the movie was a bit disappointing. It wasn't the worst Pax Romana or Volcano movie ever, but I really hope for a better movie. I wouldn't have mind, if the movie was based of the Robert Harris's novel Pompeii. At less, the Pliny the Younger quoted at the beginning of the film, would had made more sense. Honestly, I thought, at less what they could had done is add some of the real life accounts of people that was there into the fictionist story. Why quote Pliny the Younger if most of the audience have no clue, who he is? The producers could add him and his Uncle, Pliny the Elder. He was a key character in the story of Pompeii, yet he makes no appearance in the film. I found the characters in this film, one-dimensional characters including an unreasonable villain who just evil, because he just is, playing through a formulaic plot line. Directed by Paul W. S. Anderson, the movie is about a young man, Milo (Kit Harington of Games of Thrones fame), is the last surviving member of a Celts nomadic horsemen tribe that was wipe out by an evil Roman Senator named Corvus (Kiefer Sutherland). Escaping death, he only to find himself force as a slave and train as a Gladiator. When he finds himself in Pompeii, he strikes a romance with the lady Cassia (Emily Browning), only to find out, that Corvus has an eye on her as well. The movie is very similar to Ripley Scott's 2000's hit Gladiator to the point, that Milo got a black gladiator friend in Atticus (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje). The only different is that the movie turns deadly with the eruption of the volcano Vesuvius. I'm not entirely certain as to how historically accurate the film is; I have seen the Pompeii ruins some years ago, and I don't think the film got it alright. Yes, the Festival of Vinalia was going on, but, it wasn't like Bloody Olympiads. The eruption last about three days, not 24 hours. Hints why records suggest many people escaped before the city was destroyed, most of those who died were probably killed by heat shock from the pyroclastic flows. Unlike Pompeii, when the pyroclastic surges hit Herculaneum, people there were instantly killed whereas most Pompeiians slowly suffocated, although some died instantly. The movie makes it seem like it all happen in an hour, and nobody survives. I love most of the action and the special effects in the movie, but gees that's kinda a downer to invest into getting into a movie, only to have most of the character die. It was pretty pointless when you think about the corny depressing ending scene. The film poster pretty much spoils it. It's sucks more, that the movie doesn't give enough time, for us to enjoy Pompeii and its characters. We rarely see much of the city, beside one small scene where Cassia and her maid check out the street. We can't feel emotional to the people that die there or care much about the city with a short movie. Most of the film is play in the dark, where we can barely see anything. Darkness doesn't work well in 3D. Even in action scenes, we can barely see what is happening due to quick cuts and fast motion. It was so annoying. The CGI disaster part of the movie is nothing new. It looks like Roland Emmerich's 2012 in Ancient Rome. The acting in this movie is just awful. First off, Emily Browning can't put any emotion in any of her scenes. No sense of fear, remorse, or even a sign of caring is a bit off. Her character is just a Damsel in distress stereotype. Kit Harington is basically just Jon Snow in this movie. A slave since age 3, alone and horseless, hero still mastered his people's gift of horsemanship. Huh? Kit Harington can only show that he looks like Orlando Bloom and how to act uncomfortable. Kiefer Sutherland sounds like evil Peter O'Toole with a lisp. His over the top smugness is just laughable large hamming. He seem out of place jarring. Everybody play it with the Queen's Latin. Everyone speaks with a British accent except Atticus. The music and the imagery are the best from this film. The opening shot of the pre credits were pretty good. I did like the music score by Clinton Shorter. I think 2003's TV Movie, Pompeii: The Last Days probably did the movie concept better, but at less, this movie is better than 1959's The Last Days of Pompeii. Overall: Pompeii was full of clichés, lack of emotion, and miscast stars. The film isn't too bad. It can even be quite enjoyable if one doesn't expect too much.

Review title: About a history followed by a fictional tale.
Review_body: Some of Paul WS Anderson movies were awesome and some were not, mixed bag to me. It is always a tricky to choose his movies to watch. Anyway, I went for it which was based on the historic disaster subject. Something like the movie 'Titanic', only theme was based on the real, but the story was a fictional. I was curious about the merge of newly written story than what I heard about Pompeii in history books.Todays graphics on the fingertip is the reason to recreating the historic movies. The second century after the motion picture was invented is on course to right direction. Many filmmakers utilised it very well and some are overly whelmed with too much graphics like the movie '300'. But still those were awesome to revisit ancient time just like we assumed it to be while reading history books. So my expectations were usual to see men with beautiful costumes and to know more about our extinct cultures.This was the romance tale with lots of actions and adventures. This movie badly missed the star powers. Since it was a German-Canadian collaboration the cast was recruited from everywhere to make it an international product. Well, I thought the lead actor was a little short though his performance was good. The others like Emily Browning, Kiefer Southerland and Adewale were better, but the pace of the movie did not give them more opportunity to exhibit and develop their respective characters.Yes, it was the story which rushed too fast towards the ending. Another 20 minutes of drama in the initial parts would have been the perfect setup for the story like this. Especially the character Cassia needed it and also a bit Atticus before all these three meet at one point. So it seems the movie maker's plan was commercial purpose than quality of art and presentation. Anyway the entertainment was there, but not the value and standards. A slight disappointment movie, though it can be watchable at once.

Review title: Pity about the pathetic back story.
Review_body: The producers were probably hoping for a 'Titanic'-like romantic disaster film. Sadly, though, 'Pompeii' suffers from silly dialogue and unconvincing, bland acting.
