It looked like a cross between Rome and Sparta to me. The characters were all likable, and had their place in the narrative, but my main issue with the story was the classic 'Love Triangle'. I couldn't understand why a story of the famous Mount Vesuvius eruption in 79 A.D needed a sub-plot of a slave (Kit Harrington) who falls for a beautiful daughter of a wealthy merchant(Emily Browning), and ends up having to fight for her and his freedom against a corrupt Roman Senator (Keifer Sutherland).I guess you couldn't have a full movie about the eruption itself, but at the end of the day, that's all i was waiting to see. I didn't really care to much for what else was happening.When the mountain finally erupts it is spectacular. Pompeii is in deep sh*t. I liked the way the movie showed this, everyone just panicked, but there was no where to go...An entertaining end. Worth a rental in my opinion, and not really deserving of 1/10, 2/10 reviews!

Well, I thought Noah was the worst film I'd seen this year, but Pompeii beats it by some distance. Well a few cubits, perhaps. Poorly scripted, poorly acted, nice visuals, gratuitous violence, a rather loose grasp of classical history.Kiefer Sutherland proving what I'd always thought, that he's a really lousy actor ..... I was glad to see the place devoured by pyroclastic flows. That's not a spoiler, by the way, not unless you're unfamiliar with the actual place rather than the CGI splendours depicted in the movie.Garbage.

Review title: Love in the time of Destruction
Review_body: Pompeii is a great movie spectacle with good direction acting and a good deal of special effects having all the ingredients to be a very good movie which it is.The love story itself is forgettable and cheesy. But that is only incidental compared to what you can watch this movie for - its fight scenes and cataclysmic climax, both produced and recreated in good detail. Anderson cleverly cuts to the increasingly ominous rumblings of Mount Vesuvius whenever the story is in danger of dragging, to re-focus on the movie's focal point. It's not a great film, but it makes for a decent hour and forty minutes of entertainment. It's a huge improvement over THREE MUSKETEERS 3D (thankfully modern slang is mostly absent here) and will probably satisfy genre fans who just want eye candy. Keep your expectations in check and you should have a good time.

This is my first review at IMDb, and I cannot withstand from warning the people reading the reviews: this movie is very bad. If I could give a zero, I'd do that. I've read so many reviews that really helped me a lot to choose the movie I'd like to watch. Pompeii (2014) is one of a few movies I didn't inspect properly before watching. And that was a big mistake. This movie has no sense, no story, actions are amateurish, emotions are artificial, dialogues are brainless. We laughed a lot during the movie on how stupid many scenes and dialogues could be. Paul Anderson should really retire. I read his books and I liked them, but as a movie director, I'm sorry it's probably not for him. After two hours watching this movie and after the last sequence of scenes, I really wonder what all that was about? Even if considering a love genre, this movie doesn't belong to it either. Love between the main characters was very funny and superficial. Please, don't waste your time on this movie. It's completely worthless.P.S. By the way, the volcano eruption was so funny. Most of the time it shoot fire bombs instead of producing lava. And the shoots were really bully. I think Paul Anderson took this from Starship Troopers where the huge alien insects shoot the similar bombs in space.

Pompeii is probably the one city of the ancient Roman era we know the most about thanks to the fact that the eruption froze the city in time - we know what people talked about, what they worked with, what their concerns were.And yet, the one movie about the destruction of Pompeii unfortunately focuses more on a gladiator than any one else in the city. And that is so unfortunate, since with Spartacus, Gladiator and a few other features, it seems Hollywood has locked itself up with a gladiator that refuses to let them out. So instead of a movie about the actual retired Syrian marine (for example) who worked as a bronze maker and his day to day, we get another hack n' slash. it's lazy, but even worse it's plain cowardice, that Hollywood couldn't make this movie more about the actual people of Pompeii.So it was a disappointment from a script perspective, but the historical accuracy also left a lot to be desired, and the CGI was... abysmal. I'm not one who really notices matte paintings that much in movies, but here it was painfully obvious, and all the damn time.So all in all, what I thought would be a disaster movie set in history, just turned out to be something that should not have been made.Watch Gladiator, Rome or Spartacus instead. It's not about an exploding mountain, but their production values are way higher.

Review title: "the most beautiful movie i have ever seen!"
Review_body: if i were head of the academy awards, i would give this magnificent movie an academy award for music, casting, everything on the books! this is the finest, most fascinating, most beautiful movie i have seen in my long, long lifetime! how did they do it? talk about "special effects"! the eruption of the volcano that destroyed pompeii is an historical fact. but, the smoke, the noise, the fires, the ground caving in, the tidal wave caused by it, the entire earth underneath this city caving in!these people who made this movie should not only get all of the academy awards, but, go down in history for making the most technically perfect, beautiful, breath-taking, action-filled, movie ever made!! hands down! i am so glad i saw this movie tonight! i got chill bumps seeing the volcano erupt over and over! and, the beautiful music, and cinematography! magnifico!! this movie has to be one of the greatest, if not the greatest, movie ever made!

The actors and effects are alright; the plot is contrived and terribly predictable.For a film with a fair amount of swordplay there is surprisingly little blood. I'm not sure that really adds or takes anything away.Don't expect too much and you'll probably find this quite a passable affair.

Review title: A Fun Movie With Stunning Visuals... But Not So Stunning Leads...
Review_body: Pompeii is basically just Titanic with a volcano instead of a ship. But despite it copying various scenarios from Titanic, (Like the "bad guy" paying money so he can get on one of the boats to escape before anyone else) it is still a very thrilling and engaging ride. From the brutal opening scene to the sappy lame ending, it will grab a hold of your attention. Filled with stunningly beautiful visuals and well choreographed gladiator fight sequences, Pompeii has a lot of heart. It's too bad that the two lead characters were so wooden. But it's not the characters that are wooden, it's the actors. Kudos to Adewale Akkinouoye-Agbaje for giving the best performance in this movie for his portrayal of Atticus.

Review title: This is not a good movie
Review_body: I wanted to enjoy the geological pyrotechnics and hoped the plot would not be too awful. I was hoping that such things as clichéd characters and heavy usage of writer's devices would not be too apparent or off-putting. I lost hope and did not regain it even after the volcano took over and became the main event. The finale does have a sense of beauty in the image we are left to view.There is some enjoyment in the Keifer Sutherland portrayal. At one point I almost expected Keifer to spin around and do a pirouette after delivering a pique-filled pronouncement. Another reviewer here wrote Carrie Anne Moss and Keifer Sutherland have better films to show their abilities. I would agree. This film could have been better. A new script would have been a big help.September 2015 update: I can buy the 3D version for $9. 3D. $9. hmmm. I really like 3D. Quandary.

Overall the movies was good. The cast was good, it all looked very beautiful, nice fighting scenes. Okay it was full of clichés but which movie isn't?The movie was good until they entered the arena everything from there was just predictable. After the volcano erupted the movie ended for me. Okay you can have a lot of luck but really? this much? first Atticus that is running to the harbor, helps a girl and runs faster then that flood? and a boat blocks the only gate in that wall, really? of course something else that was bothering me was the always returning bad guys, they were everywhere.. During every chase the ground was falling apart and fireballs crushed near them, but when they started to fight it ALL stopped. Really?Overall the movie was good but the eruption of the volcano should have been the end for me.

Review title: Recycled Hollywood Garbage, but I found it funny
Review_body: Firstly, this movie is a complete rip-off of so many films, three specifically. The story about a slave turned gladiator was taken from the film, em... Gladiator. The fact that Milo (slave played by Kit Harrington) is seeking revenge on the Senator Corvus who murdered his family during the celtic horseman uprising, who so happens to be hosting the Gladiator event held in Pompeii where the slaves/gladiators are competing. Fine, I can let that slide. But it had too many focus points, the revenge, the love story, the friendship with a fellow combatant, and the destruction of Pompeii. It's too much, and because the love story is the main focus, and a connection with the audience is not established for the two lovers, nobody cares, so it feels like there is not stake in the story. Sure, it established that Corvus (Kiefer Sutherland) is a bad guy, and that Milo's revenge sub-plot seems a bit more investing, but I think the writers felt it couldn't be the prime focus - because that would essentially be Gladiator with a volcano.PERFORMANCES Everyone else except from the people I am going to mention just blended into the background as well, no presence.This was the main surprise for me, Kiefer Sutherland. I personally really like him, I think he's always good in whatever he is in. But, this was just so strange. I understand the dialogue he had to work with was abysmal, but some of the line deliveries in this film are some of the strangest I've ever heard in my life. They're extremely camp and out of place. The way he pouts his lips gave it some sort of f****d up lisp and he constantly delivered the normal, inside voice, lines like that. I think he did the shouting lines brilliantly, as it felt like his mouth was more natural sitting and made sense, however when he did them he did break character a few times, so maybe that lip bulls**t was to help him keep an English accent? Kit Harrington did okay as the revenge seeking gladiator lover Milo. I honestly think the standout by a mile was Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje as Atticus, 'brother' of Milo and freedom seeking gladiator. It really seemed like he was reaching into this bullshit to find the silver lining that is the corn in his lines, and I felt when he was on the screen I was engaged.NOTEWORTHY MOMENTS First, the good. The action was actually top notch. You felt the ferocity from the characters when they were hitting each other and the choreography seemed to make direct sense. It wasn't 'Phantom Menace' b******s it seemed well constructed and thought out. Having said that, the directing in some instances did my head in. the sequences were riddled in slow motion. To make it more 'epic' I presume, but it didn't.The CGI; it was either ridiculously fake looking or very well done, but just far too much. For the first point, that chase sequence mentioned in the last paragraph with Milo and Corvus holding Cassia princess big tits or whatever was hilarious. When the chase comes to a stop, the carriage Cassia was just lying in, not seat belt or rope around, goes over small ledge and flips countless times in the air before slamming into a building at high speed. Milo goes over to see if she's okay, and she's fine with not a single scratch on her.The last point is the ending. Basically what happens is that everyone dies. Milo and Cassia are the last standing and are unable to outrun the destruction. So they both lock lips and die together, which follows the most stupid moment in cinema I've seen for a long time. It shows the pair as solid rock, still locked in their kiss and embrace dead. What? If gallons of ridiculously hot magma swept over you, you'd be turned to f*****g dust. Also, because there has been no established connection between the two characters, myself as an audience member didn't care. The same goes for the general deaths of cast and extras. There's no stake, it just happens. There's no emotional connection so it's just there, happening on the screen.The only time I was sympathetic to a death was when Atticus died. This comes back to the same thing, all he wanted was freedom, he shows to be a true good guy to Milo when he saves his life, twice, and he saves a child from being swept away by Tsunami 2.0, also a stupid scene. But the point is it established an attachment to a character, who died to help Milo succeed, in which case he didn't, but his death was noble and unwanted.FINAL VERDICT The main point is that the main missing factual of the movie was emotional investment. I couldn't feel sympathetic to the two main characters bullshit love story, I couldn't be angry at the evil Corvus because Kiefer's performance was comical for the most part, and I couldn't be emotionally invested in the Mount Vesuvius volcano eruption because it was emotionless, it was a natural disaster that just happened. There was no cause, and that hindered the film. Take these examples of film - Titanic; Captain and crew's ignorance = cause for sympathy, Troy; Greek forces quest for conquering and power = cause for anger and sympathy, Gladiator; a man seeking redemption for his family's death at the hands of a tyrant = cause for hope and sympathy for character. There needs to be a reason to become emotionally involved. It's also apparent in the script, because it's mainly deprived of a recycled love story, Gladiator, and a titanic-type ending.It's recycled nonsense with some good fight scenes and two, at least, passable performances. But it doesn't make up for it. See it if you want to laugh at how bad it is, otherwise, it's a waste of time.

I expected more serious film. It is just full with modern digital effects, far from the truth what really happened in Pompeii. The millions funded the creation of this trash were wasted. The purpose of the film was to show artificial digital effects, not so successful, and cruelty because this is the way to make money in our time. Cruel, mediocre, cliché' fairy-tale. By the way – there were no black slaves in Pompeii. The director blindly followed the rule in Hollywood to put one black person in the main character at any cost, ignoring the content of the story. It is really pity to waste money for such a tasteless, incompetently created film.

I have always been fascinated about the history of Pompeii. This movie totally ruined an event that was catastrophic and turned it into a boring story. It made the plight of slaves into a cliché. A ridiculous love story. And, the actual eruption into a blase event. The acting is horrible and you got the impression that the actors were doing it to just get a paycheck. The 1980's T.V miniseries The Last Days of Pompeii was done better. If you can't find that to watch go on Netflix and watch a documentary of Pompeii. You will enjoy it more so. Skip this one and if you did watch it try to forget it. It shouldn't be difficult.

Review title: A disaster movie that doesn't turn out to be such a disaster as some would've expected
Review_body: Paul W. S. Anderson might not be the most reliable director in Hollywood nowadays, but not the most unreliable either, having under his belt some decent movies too, like for instance: Event Horizon and Mortal Kombat( please don't judge). The movie is about the last days of the eponymous city of Pompeii, whose story I bet you already know by now. The movie is told from the eyes of Kit Harington's character,a gladiator called Milo, who has Celtic origins.(YES!, Kit Harington the guy from Game of Thrones, who knows nothing) This gladiator is on his way to the big city where he will have to face a lot of challenges like love, and a few smaller problems like gladiator fights and an exploding volcano, but nothing can beat love. Kit Harington does a good job in the movie, here I'm not referring just to his six pack, but also to his acting. Don't expect anything Oscar worthy. He has just the right amount of energy for this role and also the right physique :). Through the movie the character makes some bonds and enemies too, and you can feel his motivation through the whole movie. The supporting cast also does a terrific job, especially Kiefer Sutherland as the movie's main villain ( beside the volcano) whom Milo hates so much, having a pretty good reason for doing so. The movie's first part takes place in the yet not stricken city of Pompeii, these thrills are mostly given by the well executed gladiator fight scenes and the bonding that happens between the characters. As the disaster kicks in, the movies quality slowly decreases( or that was how it seemed to me), because for those who know about what really has happened in the city of Pompeii will know that there are some things that just don't belong there and some will notice that the length of the disaster is pretty shortened, but I bet all these things were added/changed for artistic purpose and to make the movie more intense, probably this will succeed with those who are less familiar with the history of the city. Despite the inaccuracy, there is one thing that I have to praise when it comes to the second part, and that's the use of the visual effects and also the use of 3D, which many of us already consider pretty annoying and distracting, but it was a good surplus to this movie. Another problem of the movie is its familiarity, its plot is very generic, as many have already described it, it's just a Titanic set in Pompeii. Everything that's going to happen its pretty guessable. In conclusion I would like to say that despite its problems the movie was an enjoyable popcorn flick, due to its good use of the effects and also the good use of 3D. Those who'll watch the movie don't expect anything Oscar worthy, because it's not, but it's something that you'll be entertained by, and this is what the movie does the best, it entertains, probably that can be owed to Paul W. S. Anderson's previous blockbuster attempts. Also don't expect a faithful representation of the disaster, because that's not what the movie tries to do.

If you are expecting to see a 'movie' be prepared to be utterly disappointed. If you want to watch an hour and a half of special effects and somehow can ignore everything else, this one is for you. I like special effects myself, i enjoy 3d movies and so no, but i found it impossible to ignore the rest of the movie witch was so horrible it would be a thousand times better if it was scripted by my cat while it is shitting in the litter box. To describe better why it is painful to watch, imagine someone putting a gorilla witch just underwent a lobotomy in a formula 1 race car and starting it. Or making it write the script for a 100 000 000 budget movie, same o.

That was how Pliny the Younger began his letter to Emperor Titus as he carefully recounted his own experiences on the day Vesuvius erupted, and it is how I begin this review today.Though my mind shrinks from remembering, I will begin. It was an awful work. A mindless film with no redeeming qualities other than some cheap effects. The Vesuvius eruption is overwrought with scene of things that never occurred. Balls of fire, giant tsunamis, buildings razed that still stand today. Historically vacuous. Well, maybe the story was good, you'll say. No, no it wasn't. It was a simplistic story of star-crossed lovers, one a rich maiden, and the other slave. Sound familiar. Of course it does. Some would say it is a ripoff of Titanic, but it is far worse than that. It isn't even good enough to warrant the Harlequin press logo. The villain is a senator who dresses like an Emperor, and does Emperor like things to invoke Commodus from Gladiator. He is played poorly by the otherwise talented Kiefer Sutherland, who can't choose an accent. I can't stress enough that the whole film is drivel from start to finish. The fight scenes have been done a hundred times, and are nothing but yawn inducing. The characters do nothing to cause you to care about them. In fact, as others have said, you can't wait to see how the volcano swallows them up.I don't watch Game of Thrones so i don't know how talented the male lead is supposed to be, but he stinks here. Don't waste your time.

Review title: Hollywood keeps doing its tricks to lure your money.
Review_body: Again Hollywood execs decided to redo some scenes of Troy, Gladiator and Titanic. First step was to find an Orlando Bloom lookalike, second find a script written by some high school kids and finally... use an Apple II for special effects. There you have it, a disastrous disaster movie.Certainly a movie using Pompeii as location should use in its scenes places that former visitors can relate to, not just the colliseum. I kept waiting for the flour mill & bakery, the frescoes and the bath houses. If the script writer had taken the time to visit Pompeii before writing this movie his work would be a lot better... oh, I forgot, the kids were at school an the script was just a weekend homework.A horse joined Milo and Cassia, then Cassia's horse rejoined them again, hey!, it's a love story, what happened to Cassia's horse. Milo should have it on hand to save her in the final scenes, celluloid is an expensive thing to waste when your'e filming clitches.So folks, don't waste your time, if you pay to watch this movie you are sending a wrong signal to Hollywood.

No. So inaccurate for the sake of special effects it is laughable. John Snow ends up in an eighth kingdom, taking on and beating all comers, regardless of their size and, just like Kiefer in 24, absorbing endless punishment with no lasting effect apparent for his next fight. Where is truth in film nowadays? Like Orlando Bloom in Kingdom of Heaven, Kit Harrington lacks the machismo to make his character's role believable. He is not a Crowe (no pun intended for GoT fans) and certainly not a romantic lead. The acting is wooden, the script cliché ridden and dire, being a series of unlikely cameos interspersed with Saturday afternoon movie destruction. Go mow the grass instead.

I had hopes walking into this film. Not high hopes, but hopes none the less. With a reasonable cast attached to this project, I was hoping for a solid story line attached to a history lesson. What we got was a bunch of clichés thrown together that, if you've seen Gladiator or any of Roland Emerich's disaster films, you'll feel like you've seen this movie before.Of course, if you've heard of Pompeii, than you probably know of its demise at the hands of an erupting Mt Vesuvius. The Roman town's final days are the backdrop for a love story set in the time of swords and sandals. Milo (Kit Harrington) is a skilled gladiator, sent to the doomed coastal city on his master's behest, to entertain the crowds in battle within the colosseum. He of course attracts the attention of Cassia (Emily Browning), daughter of the town's rulers (Jared Harris and Carrie-Anne Moss, both horribly underused), who, in turn, is being pursued by the conniving Senator Corvus (Keither Sutherland). Corvus, in typical movie story overlay, is responsible for the death of Milo's family when he was just a boy, and his clichèd bad guy ticks all the usual and predictable boxes. As a clash between Milo and Corvus comes to a head, Mt Vesuvius performs its party piece, and the movie turns into a survival quest for all its leads, with Milo and Cassia doing everything to escape the impending doom raining down on the city, as well as the wrath of Corvus and his cohorts.As I mentioned before, if you've seen Gladiator or any disaster film of recent, than you can pretty much take a guess at what your in for here. In fact, I wouldn't be surprised if director Paul W.S. Anderson had a few viewing of Ridley Scott's Gladiator before making this film, as some of the scenes are almost taken verbatim. There was one section of this film where I took a guess at a spoken line that was coming up, simply because it looked like a remake of a scene from Scott's classic. Sure enough, a few seconds later, up it popped. The storyline is so disappointingly stock-standard, and you can't help but feel that the studio executives wanted to make a movie about the destruction of Pompeii, and simply threw a half-hearted effort of a script at it.The performers do what they can, but they're given precious little to work with. Harrington, looking ultra buff I must say, does OK with his lead role, but doesn't really test himself away from his Games of Thrones typecast. Its disappointing, as I've quite liked Harrington's effort in GOT, and I hope he gets another chance to prove himself on the big screen. Sutherland is disappointingly clichèd in his bad guy role, and his attempt at an English accent is rather cringeworthy at times. Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje stands out as the best performance from this, with his role as Milo's gladiatorial compatriot, Atticus, the only shining light on what is mostly disappointing.But I suspect the cast have been let down by what really is a rather cut-and-paste script. There's no twists, no real drama built. All the characters story lines are just sideshows to the main event, which is the eruption. The effects of mountain's final display and its subsequent destruction of Pompeii is pretty impressive, and is by far and away the best part of this film. However, its not enough to rescue this flick. Anyone hoping for a history lesson from this film will be sorely disappointing, as precious little is garnered about life in Pompeii, and, from memory, I'm not even sure the name of the mountain is mentioned even once.This isn't a terrible film, but its just such a disappointment that Anderson and Co. decided to make such a routine effort of a film. I can't remember the last time a blockbuster film genuinely gave me a mental workout, or provided a plot twist that shocked or surprised me. Pompeii didn't do the job, and I didn't exactly learn anything either. Some originality here would've been much appreciated.

Review title: Horrifying Chain of Events Converted to Romantic & Thrilling Saga !
Review_body: You all might know that Pompeii has a historic value not only for it's representation of culture, villas, erotic art or town planning, but also to remind us all that we all live on mercy of nature.Movie is wrapped in similar chain of events and consequences leading to horrific end of Pompeii. Interesting part though is how it is represented by the director. I do not blame people who say it is worse disaster movie or has a gladiator feel to it. The fact is, it is neither a disaster movie nor a mix of Titanic and Gladiator.This movie is all about relationships, love and human endurance to nature's one of the biggest blows. Depth of it touches different classes of people in same society and the division and unrest among the community during time of Roman era. Movie also questions moral decisions over gladiator fights and killing of our own race to display superiority. Which is still going on even after 2000 years. Among this hard won battles and blood socked bodies lies an unconditional love showcasing a devotional perspective of one for betterment of other half. Though death is an inevitable part of our life, there is a value attached to it, and the movie hold itself to it.CGI in the movie is very good and does impress on some of the scenes as I saw it in 3D. Sound editing and background score are excellent and so as sound effects.Acting is also very good and keep you in grip. There are no shuffles of scenes and all important characters are given enough time to bond with each other.Overall, it is surely a watchable movie with an open mindset without expecting it to be a end of the world or gladiator type.

Review title: An Actually Good Disaster Movie That's Not A Disaster
Review_body: Pompeii is directed by Paul W.S. Anderson, and centers around the character of Milo, who is a man that stands against the Roman empire after he is put into slavery and becomes a gladiator in Pompeii. He befriends a fellow gladiator and slave Atticus, who helps him fight back against Rome and also ventures to save Cassia, who is to be married to Senator Corvis, a corrupt official.The movie is actually not as bad as i thought it was going to be. Sure, it is still not an award-winning masterpiece like Gladiator, but for a CG-filled action-fest about Pompeii, it actually worked well. The visual effects were very good (the effects that were made for 3D weren't as much), the musical score by Clinton Shorter was great (echoing the greatness of Gladiator, Kingdom of Heaven and even Game of Thrones), and Anderson's directing, i personally would say is his best here. Now, the acting, i have mixed feelings for. Emily Browning was good as Cassia (nothing amazing), Kiefer Sutherland was great as an antagonist, and Kit Harrington was (sadly) not as good as he is in Game of Thrones, but still good. The show-stealer is Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje as Atticus, who is very similar to that of Djimon Hounsou in Gladiator, and for me, his performance brought tears.Pompeii is not a classic in any sort of way, but is one i would definitely see again and own when it's released on disc. I never would have thought this movie would be actually good, but i hope they have an extended cut for a disc release because they could have made the movie longer.

I tried to enjoy this movie, even though I knew it wouldn't be anything special. I will admit it was good enough, but had so much more potential. The greatest scenes were ruined by cheesiness and camera shots that have been done so many times in movies that it is made easy to call out what will happen next. However, this wasn't my biggest issue with the movie.This is rated PG-13, so obviously the violence cannot be gory in any way. So a note to the director: when someone slashes another's face with a sword (an act that would be very bloody, as we've seen in many R rated movies), DO NOT show the face! Either keep the face out of the shot and let the audience imagine how bad the wound is, or make it gory and risk the R rating! Instead, the director shows the face after it gets slashed, but there isn't a mark on said face, even though they just got hit with a sword! And this happens several times throughout the movie...it really takes away from the fighting sequences when there's no actual wounds on anyone.Characters are very poorly developed. The only thing I took from this movie was that Mr. Eko from LOST and some really ripped guy are trying to be like Maximus and defy Rome.Enough bad. This movie was an entertaining hour and a half. The length is perfect for the material. The ending came fast but it was fairly well done, a lot better than I assumed it would be. The action was interesting and frequent enough to keep my attention, despite a love story that I frankly could care less about due to the fact that I don't know anything about the characters. It's worth a rent, but maybe not the $10 at theaters.

Review title: Minor flaws throughout, but otherwise a solid thrill...
Review_body: I would want to say that this film feels different, yet somehow it felt  familiar. The film felt different thanks to the climactic volcanic  eruption, which added an extra dimension to the final act, yet in every  other minor plot detail, it felt as if I've seen the act many times  before. Overall, though, it is a joy to watch, despite the minor flaws  throughout the film.  One strong point in which I enjoy the film were the action sequences,  which mostly are very practical sword fights, that turns out to be  quite fun and enjoyable with the fast & swift hits. And then throughout  the end, the suspense of the danger can be felt, which I attribute  mostly to the decent soundtrack. Soundtracks which are supportive  towards the appropriate situation is always a great thing to have. And  while the visual effects were not perfect, it didn't really matter in  terms of the overall experience.  Yet the film is dragged down by minor flaws along the way. There was no  humour in the mix, and while there is no deep emotional drama as well,  at least I can still feel for the character. There are times where I  felt that the scenes were not supposed to happen yet, although in the  end, I could at least care about what's going to happen to these  characters. And the closing scenes were too abrupt, where they could  instead have added some finishing lines/quotes or maybe give some  aftermath/future scenes. These minor details kind of let down what  would otherwise be a solid thrilling disaster film.  VERDICT:  Good: Great action sequences, Decent soundtrack & suspense  Bad: No humour, Lack of emotional touches, Abrupt ending, (Minor flaws)  SCORE: 7.0

Review title: "Spartacus meets Gladiator", and oh yeah there's a Volcano
Review_body: Why would you completely change a story that was already so compelling and well known? And why would you avoid being at all historically accurate, and replace the majority of the story with one that is poorly written and directed, and containing characters and events that were never there? Toss in plenty of cheap dialog, and then at the end we'll do a volcano that does things completely differently than what actually happened. I suppose if you know absolutely nothing about Pompeii and Vesuvius then you might watch this movie and thing it was OK. But even then, it's only OK at best. But this is such a well know story these days, and the actual history was so well documented, I doubt there are too many people that could watch this and not notice some incredible inaccuracies. Then there's the fact that the real story is one that wrote itself - the actual events were far more compelling and gripping than the ones in this movie. So you have to ask - what were they thinking? A one hour show on the History Channel was far better, and more gripping. Pass on this one.

Review title: You know nothing about volcanoes Jon Snow!
Review_body: One does not simply walk into Pompeii. Read the cast list. It is the best part of this entire film. From there it goes down hill faster than a pyroclastic flow. If you only expect a 60's styled B- movie gladiator Shake'n'Bake then you will thoroughly enjoy this film. However, unlike some really horrible movies out there, this one at least is not impossible to watch so don't pass this up if you have some time to kill. But when you do, suspend everything you have ever watched about real volcano eruptions we have witnessed in real time during the past 40 years. It is just a moderately interesting love story set amongst some Mordor-like CGI. And like the movie Titanic, we know how this story ends.
Enjoyable romp and romance, great cgi, with plenty of action. If you are looking for historical accuracy, then it's probably best you turn over to the History channel.

The story of Pompeii would have deserve a much better movie that this pile of goofs. I have never seen a longer list of goofs and mistakes. Many of then very obvious... from falling fire rocks to huge tsunami waves. But to be honest, without this absurd and bizarre exaggerations there would not be any special effects so no movie. "The crow" was a big disappointment, like the rest of the cure. It's a shame. They should never been let to make this movie so poor. Pompeii is my favorite historical event and then I first saw the title on IMDb I was eager to see the film. I had big expectations but Hollywood just wasted more cash on behalf of history.

Definitely worth for your money. Looking at the rating i was in a doubtful mind whether to go to the movie or not, but finally decided to go as I took off for the day from office. Director made sure that you will not get bored for a single minute during the movie run.Plus points: 1. 3D effects are awesome. Mount Vesuvius eruption was shown superbly and ash combined with fire looked like real. 2. Emily Browing looks fresh and well suited for her role. 3. Finally Kiefer Sutherland got a good full length role in a movie. 4. Gladiator's fighting scenes are highlight for the movie.Negatives: 1. Very less emotion quotient. 2. A famous hero might have attracted more audience to the theater and more ratings. 3. Few scenes are obvious and can be predicted. 4. Finally in India break was given in the middle of the fight scene in amphitheater which killed the momentum of the movie.

Review title: Dreadful except for Jon Snow's abs
Review_body: Wow was this bad. It seems that Jon Snow has only one possible emotion a subtle emo-looking petulant scowl (just like in Game of Thrones)but his abs are in better shape here, though they do look like they could be plastic. Or CGI. Remember when everyone said the abs were CGI in 300? Sort of like that.Anyway it's no spoiler or anything but the big volcano erupts. And everyone runs toward the sea carrying a small canvas bag of something. I mean, everyone. They must have passed them out at Pompeii Disaster Central - get your canvas bag now and run to the sea everyone before you lie down and hold hands in the ashes that will be here for 2000 years!But then the harbor has issues, like the ocean recedes and turns into a big tidal wave! Oh no, head for the hills!I read somewhere this was in 3D which makes sense (since I watched it in 2D) why all this stuff was being thrust and flaming rocks were falling from the sky and they were flying right into the cameras.There is no plot, well OK, a feeble plot that seemed to take part of Gladiator and that Clive Owen version of King Arthur and that LA Volcano movie with Tommy Lee Jones and create a hella mashup with Jon Snow and Trinity in a bit part (I mean Trinity, from the Matrix - how long since she's been on-screen - in a word - whoa).She gets about the lamest death scene ever because the coliseum in Pompeii falls on her. Keifer Sutherland meanwhile, who seems to be wearing an ill-fitting set of false teeth is mugging around trying to be evil which fails miserably. Not for anything but even with his mugging and terrible bit of acting he still seems like he could bitch-slap Jon Snow into next week.Jon Snow is not much of a hero. He is a good fighter but it's a little hard to buy his baby face as the Harbinger Celt of Doom. His love interest (the girl who was in Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events who seemed to finally grow into her lips)has nothing to do but cling to his abs (Thank you Jon Snow for rescuing me with your CGI abs)and then gets kidnapped by Keifer and driven in a chariot to where? He thinks he's going to outrun the volcano and get to Rome in a chariot? At one point there is mass destruction, the volcano is erupting and these two idiots are having a sword fight. What is the point of that? To die a couple of minutes sooner? I mean this is bad. I don't think I even made it to the end, or possibly I did but I can't remember. I did like Jon Snows abs. I think he will be very hot when he finishes growing up. Meanwhile I prefer keeping up with him on Game of Thrones where Jon Snow can be the moody, scowling bastard he is.

Review title: If you want a good volcano movie, watch Dante's Peak
Review_body: OK so I assumed, shame on me, that this was going to be a good disaster movie. I didn't expect much else I have to admit.But it wasn't even that. It was a rip-off of Gladiator and Conan The Barbarian, with a volcano thrown in.It's mostly a lame love story and so cliché I started wondering, when the hell is the damn volcano going to erupt to end all this.If you want a good disaster movie involving a volcano, watch Dante's Peak. Much better and very realistic in terms of the events before, during and after a volcanic eruption.
I'm guessing they didn't get the memo that this movie was already made.... Only 100 times better than this.

I watched this for Kit Harrington. To see him in something else besides GOT. Well, at least he knew something. But there are so many stereotypes. Boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl back, boy kisses girl, they both die. Atticus dying "I die free", shades of STARGATE and nobody gets out alive!

I've been trying to come up with a good reason as to why "Pompeii" should receive something less than a "10" but after giving much thought, I couldn't come up with anything. There wasn't anything about it I didn't like. You have to have your obligatory love story, with intrusion by the villain who wants to ruin everything so this must be expected. The acting was very descent and big name stars were not needed to carry it, though Kiefer Sutherland does play a convincing Roman senator, determined to take our Princess heroine back to Rome. She's not interested as she has the eye for "The Kelt", the gladiator who seems invincible and also determined to claim his love interest. All the while, the famous eruption is building and when all breaks lose, it's a feast for the eyes. The special effects crew deserves special credit for their work on "Pompeii". Some of the finest effects I've seen. Nothing hokey, just a good old fashioned disaster flick that leaves no room for cheesy humor. The movie wasn't overly long, running at about 1:45 hrs so things moved along at a good clip. I will not share the ending as you must see for yourself. All in all, I'm thrilled to have this on Blu Ray.
It's a good action paced movie which was well acted. Just a solid watchable movie. Kept me engaged and interested in the characters which is all you can ask for.

As you can see, I rated it 9/10,so that means I really enjoyed in this movie. It had few of my favorite actors "John Snow" and "Mister Eko". OK, now lets get to the point. What really impressed me in this movie, was Pompeii city itself. I watched some documentary on TV few months ago, about historical fate of that city. To be able to see the entire city of Pompeii like its presented in this movie, it is amazing. And the love story had some of the best endings, it made me to share tear. Special effects are really well done, and acting is good, but it had some unnecessary moments, especially with sound of horses, and entire "horse" background story (I guess they were to lazy into development of the characters) maybe its better, because in the end I would cry for real.Very interesting movie, with some scenes you can fast forward. I recommend it to everyone. It is also great, that we are able to present how ancient cities looked like and what happened to them, I am not sure if everything about city Pompeii is as it is shown in this movie, but looks like it was great city with a lot of people in it, and in this way , this movie is for them. For all those people that lost their lives on that tragic apocalyptic day.As far as I am concerned, they should create documentary series, with Computer-generated imagery used in this movie, and tell stories about other cities, that we used to have back in history, and they are now lost. How they never saw it coming?

Review title: A watered down sequel to the Spartacus series?
Review_body: Okay my apologizes for presuming in the title that viewers and fans of this movie also have seen the famous Starz series 'Spartacus'. Btw if you like this genre and have not then you should.Back to Pompeii - certainly have a nice thread of a story of a destitute boy turned slave turned gladiator. And then as icing throw in the angle of revenge and romance. Was a great setup hell even better than Spartacus. However the movie lost it as trying too hard to play on the lines of the Starz series and therefore being overshadowed by it. To add to the watering down was some poor acting by the lead actor, actress and his gladiator buddy. Matter of fact the villain camp starting with the corrupt senator did a much better acting job. The fights were a complete miss in one instance a gashed neck produces no blood! Better acting and rock solid production would have made this movie a classic but alas it was not to be.

As much as I like Game of thrones star Kit Harington, I had the feeling he wasn't exactly appropriate as main character in a movie.The story is very predictable, but that wouldn't have necessarly been a problem if it was well made.The first part of the movie is very slow, but suddenly towards the end there's a lot going on.The main character doesn't speak much and if he does he's not very convincing.Plus, between him and the main female character there is no chemistry.The funny thing was that the other gladiator has a funny accent, kind of like Jamaican. It could've been a great movie, because the story line was pretty interesting, but that's a missed opportunity.
After watching Season 8 of the Game of Thrones, you'll realize this ain't so bad. No longer the worst on Kit Harington's resume.

Review title: In overall a decent movie, yet to those who hate lack of detail will find it worth passing by
Review_body: Where to start on this one? The thing is that this movie should cover one of Europe's biggest ancient catastrophes and should be based on actual events. Throughout the film it is clear that it lacks any historical value what so ever.Let's start at the beginning. Celtic village being destroyed, all but one child being slaughtered, he sees the murders faces, runs away from his town, being captured by slave-handlers... Fast forward to Londinium, he became a gladiator, invincible to all and is qualified to go to Pompeii. Fast forward, being led to Pompeii, accidentally meets the girl who falls in love with him, arrives at the arena, meets his opponent, etc etc... You don't have to have seen a lot of films to recognize the base storyline that they want to told. It's a copy of other movies who've chosen this base-story so in a way, this script wasn't as surprising as I expected it to be.Moving forward, the clichés pile up as he meets the girl in her house at a party, he sees the murderers of his village, the "bad guy" wants to marry the girl he loves, he and his fellow gladiator have to fight along against the bad guys, the girl is put in a dangerous situation by the bad guy so Milo has to save her, they both die at the end... You can see the story unfold itself right at the beginning of the movie, so basically, that's a huge spoiler. Yet again, if you don't mind the weak storyline, this is a decent movie to watch.If we have to discuss the eruption and all of the disaster that comes along with it, I have seen more than one mistake pass by. 1) The arena wasn't destroyed during a quake prior to the eruption. Visiting Pompeii you'll see the arena still standing like nothing happened. 2) Continuous rain of fire. When a volcano explodes, a few lava rocks may be shot into the air, but there's no continuous rain of fire. Great effect, but boring after a while and even unbelievable to see them coming bolt after bolt, like some meteor shower. 3) Cracking grounds as they drive along the (suddenly empty) streets of Pompeii whilst buildings collapse near them. No street in Pompeii shows any gaps or destruction marks indicating the ground has cracked open. Yet, great effect but highly unlikely this happened. 4) Gasping for air as she inhaled dust and ashes that dwell in the air. They give her something to drink and she's fine again. Having ash in your lungs it is not advisable to drink since you'll create a thick muddy layer. She should have suffocated instead of running in the streets. 5) Unless you're superman, you can't outrun an upcoming tsunami (which wasn't created by a blast of the exploding top, this should have caused more buildings to collapse) 6) A thin layered concrete rune-stone in an arena with a metal-wired skeleton. Romans were great builders, but that technique wasn't described during roman period... And I have some more minor errors but hey, let's not spoil the fun.But my biggest issue is the use of the casted bodies. Don't make one up. The casted "sculpture" of Milo and Cassea at the end was great for a dramatic ending, but doesn't exist in real life. Why did the director not choose an existing casted body that lies in real Pompeii? There are numeral breathtaking castings he could've used as a final shot. To make one up, along with the dramatic effects that didn't occur in real life, is kinda like making the whole event up. For being based on a real event, it didn't felt real to me, as the whole movie felt plastic, artificial and unbelievable. Despite the acting (which was okay for some and great for others), I didn't buy the story. And I believe that buying the story, especially on this dramatic event, is essential.So, in overall, if you're looking for a mindless evening of movie theater, with a story you don't have to think about and packed with action and drama... This is your thing. For those who we're willing to learn more about Pompeii and what happened, I advise you youtube where there are more suitable documentary's for you to learn something about the eternal city and what actually happened that day. With more depth and even better storyline.

Review title: 300 meets volcanos!! I loved it! has to be up there with my fav films!
Review_body: Paul WS Anderson brings us a spectacular Roman film! One of the best I've seen. I really don't know where to start with it, so I'll say the negatives first. I thought it was a little Clichéd. The characters said and did things that definitely would only happen in movies. For example, when Milo is chasing Cassia and and Corvus on his horse, when he nearly gets covered in ash, we all knew he was gonna come back out... The next bad thing would have to be, i thought they totally forgot what happened to Phoenix. They also seemed to forget about the Volcano erupting at times. (I don't wanna say I know how Volcano's erupt...)Right now onto the positives. 1 word. CGI. The CGI in this film is some of the best, it tops Gravity. OK it tops GRAVITY. In this film they recreated the eruption of Pompeii perfectly. I couldn't have asked for anything better. Also I thought Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje gave a great performance as Atticus and definitely deserves recongition. Kit Harrington could have given a great performance but failed to deliver. But it doesn't matter because I loved the CGI so much.Anyway to sum up 10 out of 10 because the CGI has blown me away, i struggled to believe it was fake. DEFIANTLY WATCH IN 3D!!!!

Review title: Visual effects try to make it up for the lack of decent narration
Review_body:
Classic example of Hollywood movie in which the massive use of special effects tries to cover the mediocrity of the narrative. The storyline is shallow, unrealistic, full of already heard lines and dynamics. The only element of surprise in the narrative might be the ending, which is instead the part where an already seen and predictable happy ending would have been the best choice to give a meaning to the overall story.
The soundtrack is beautiful, but not much space is given to it.

No words I'm really enjoyed.
paul proved he is a best director.

This movie has amazing cinematography from capturing scenes of two main slaves that turn to ruthless gladiators taking back there freedom. Turning Into a earthly disaster from ground breaking elements while still highlighting the fact of the will they have to fight and survive during this disaster. Such a captivating storyline with amazing acting!! Must watch.

This is just specious history tied to politically correct anachronisms. It seems that well-done historical films had a very short run. They were laughable during Hollywood's so-called golden age, and then we had one brief, shining era-epitomized by the Merchant Ivory films--and now, multicultural over-sensitivity coupled with lack of research has brought us to the current (probably irreversibly) degenerate phase.

With a director like Paul W.S. Anderson you kinda know what you're gonna get: eye candy, devoid of any emotion, characterization, or logic. But it's usually nice to look at. Same here. I enjoyed the establishing shots of Pompeii before the volcano eruption, and I certainly enjoyed the mayhem during the eruption. There's a fine 15-minute demo reel in here somewhere. Unfortunately the visual effects are far more convincing than any of the human characters, who are suffering from cliché-ridden dialog and wildly inconsistent, borderline ridiculous behaviour; Kiefer Sutherland is fearlessly over-acting, while Kit Harrington does not act at all, he just pouts and gazes into the camera with his sick-puppy-look. I won't even begin to list all the historic inaccuracies, as there are way too many and there's a maximum of 1.000 words for this review. So if you want to watch this movie, go ahead. You could do worse. But then again, there are so many better movies out there, why waste your time with this dribble?

Review title: Good to see flesh on the bones of Pompeii
Review_body: If you've been to Pompeii you'll recognize its landmarks and appreciate their reconstruction here, but like another reviewer noted, this film is little more than a guilty pleasure for those of us who dig Roman ruins. It has a similar storyline to Gladiator but the plot is even thinner, sorry no Oscars for acting here but the volcano is awesome and bombards you with 3-D fireballs and a storm of ash-flakes. This has been called a love story, but what ardor there is is only telegraphed by longing stares at a distance and across the gulf between slave and highborn.(Spoiler Alert) The romance is finally consummated in a single kiss at the end that gets immortalized in one of those famous plasters of Pompeii's moments of death before we go to black. I would much rather have seen Robert Harris' "Pompeii" translated to the screen, at least it had a decent plot. There was a project to make it into a movie, but alas it never materialized.

Review title: Overall a good movie. Director said he directed it as a disaster movie
Review_body: Every single fact aside, as in 99.9% of all movies, I enjoyed this movie very much. The Special effects were very good, and did not look like everything was done in front of a green screen. I particularly looked at the large crown scenes and found many people or things moving throughout the scenes. Every movie of this type is based on very little eye witness, there was virtually nothing written back then, so today we do the best we can to relate what happened. In this case, I think it was done well. The biggest mistake in casting was the roll of Cassia. I was much more moved with Ariadne. In my opinion, she was more beautiful and sensitive than Cassia, although if I could have had my pick, I would have chosen Milo. He was stunningly gorgeous.

Let's be fair the movie is good. I mean you won't be regretful about watching the movie and it won't disappoint you. For me it's just an amusing movie that I enjoyed watching. The first 30 minutes are good to see and make sense. The mid 30 minutes are a little (or more than a little) boring but don't haste! The last 30 minutes are very promising and we'll undoubtedly entertain you. Visual Effects are amazing and in my opinion they're far far better than the extremely absurd 300: Rise of an Empire. Colors are vivid. Pompeii is beautiful. Emily is pretty and she acts good. Kit is cute but his performance isn't that sexy at all. Kiefer somehow disappointed me. His performance is lost and he's just a simple villain! Trinity (from the Matrix) does fine. I give it 6 out of then and it deserves it for sure.

I read the other reviews, and agree with the few who understood that this was just a fictional story set in a real time, a contrived action movie set in an actual historic major disaster. I wasn't in the mood for anything deep or life-changing. I just wanted to take a break and watch an action film, and I got that. I wanted to like the main characters and to see the bad guys get their comuppance, and I got that. I wanted cool special effects, and I got them in spades!
I had a fun afternoon and enjoyed every single minute of this movie.

So: Again a catastrophe film like Titanic. with the same abysmal and unbelievable character writing. Add actors that are far to good in other movies to be in this drivel. Ad writers from such *great* movies like Batman -ForeverYou end with a silly love story without any actual depth - and just happens to occur along a major know catastrophe-- sorry guys but Catastrophe movies are bad for a reason.- End result known. and not much of a villain in the form of mountains or icebergs.... it just becomes settings.- Just like Titanic.To garnish this dish: copy almost directly gladiator fights, settings, even bloody ad-verbatim dialog!from the Gladiator movie. = end result bad shrimp cocktail - that will make you sick- or spit it out.Highlights... : Kit- still Knows Nothing. Emily- could have made this movie kick ass if she pulled out a few guns and started shooting Steam Nazi Zombies near the end---- around midway I started to nod off and dream of this. Kiefer- got to practice a seriously interesting accent- never heard before and kept me curious throughout the movie. Considering a fair budget and fair actors... I can only blame writers and directors for making this.In our time; are writers really the thing to get from the discount bin? seriously? There are /fic writers out there with higher skill..

The movie Pompeii was obviously thought-up and directed around the 3D effects. The plot, acting, and script must have all been after-thoughts to the 3D fireballs shooting off the screen, 3D ashes floating in front of your eyes, and the 3D objects being hurled around by tidal waves.It was watchable, but don't be expecting a fabulous plot that you haven't seen dozens of times in other better movies. The bad writing had most of the actors come off sounding like lifeless wooden statues that would say and do very unbelievable things just to keep the story going. Everything was very predictable. So predictable, in fact, there were a couple of moments I could have sworn I did see it before!This was a good example why I typically do no like 3D movies. Having some good 3D effects is not a valid excuse for making a bad movie!! This definitely could have been much better!

Review title: POMPEII flooded by tsunami – interesting new angle of view :-((
Review_body: The actual highlight of this movie –exc. for Harrington's Abs ;-)– its special effects, are also its downfall in my eyes.At first I admired the CPU-created buildings for their naturalness. Next I was slightly shocked by a "kind-savage-wins-lady's-heart-through-horse" clichè. Very 2-dimensional. (The gladiator bit tries to summon up all "Spartacus" series in a nutshell.)But when a tsunami gets to Pompeii that was too much for me. ... AND volcano bomb-shells exploding ... arrrrrgh! Not much real history in this story.The unplanned funny end is two lovers frozen in a kiss (like plaster figures gained from voids in real Pompeii houses).

Kit Harington, the brooding raven locked bastard son in Game of Thrones, brings his smolder to Paul WS Anderson's Roman disaster epic. He's was an orphaned child of Rome's brutality. Now older, with a major chip on his boulder-like deltoids he's a champ gladiator headed for destiny in the wrong city. One that's about to be ash-fired in a volcano pizza oven. Unfortunately that's about it. Rounded up, we have possibly fifteen minutes of Kit's sculpted abs, yum ladies, Kit's drilling glare and Kit in tunic riding a steed. Some fancy gladiatorial sword play and brilliant CGI of Vesuvius laying waste to the city - not much else. Oh there is some feeble sentiment about the corruption of Rome offered by a mollycoddled Cassia (Emily Browning), daughter of the keeper of the city of Pompeii. If its sword and sandal pathos you want, you could find more in Ridley Scott's arena sand - re-watch Gladiator.

While not a classic, Pompeii is actually a pretty enjoyable disaster/action flick that I couldn't wait to see back in 2014. I remember enjoying it in cinemas and have just watch it again for the 2nd time. I really need to get around to watching the 24 minutes of cut footage as I feel several characters were highly underused, especially Carrie Ann Moss and Jessica Lucas. While the ending still kinda annoys me, I really don't think it could've ended any other way.It's fast paced, has some great action scenes and is an overall pretty decent. Nowhere near as bad as others are making out to be. I wish Emily Browning would make more big budget movies.

Review title: One of the easiest events in history to research, but they didn't
Review_body: The screenwriters and production designers didn't even have to read. There are any number of excellent podcasts they could have binged over a casual weekend walking their dogs and drinking coffee. It would been so easy to get things right, from the geography to the costumes to what actually went on in the games. From the social structure and politics, from what a senator was and what power he had (and didn't have). From how the actual eruption unfolded. Apparently that was too much trouble, just as it was too much trouble for Kiefer Sutherland to commit to his (unnecessary) English accent.

Review title: Friends don't let friends watch Pompeii!
Review_body: It was PROFOUNDLY horrible!! 1 Star- and that's only for Kit Harington's chest.My husband and I both love historical drama and the cataclysm at Pompeii seemed a good enough backdrop. But the project was written and green lighted by people who clearly didn't bother to consult a historian. Or an archaeologist. Or Wikipedia. There was a clear and fundamental absence of understanding of Roman history, culture, social structure, and politics, of Roman combat methods and formations, of vulcanology, of the facts and history surrounding Pompeii, of the way the people of Pompeii died or of the quickness in which they were overtaken- even of the differences between Rome and Greece, or of the fact that Pompeii WAS in fact part of Rome. It was a shocking embarrassment with perhaps the WORST script and storyline ever. (Seriously- the script was SHOCKINGLY BAD!) We truly have no idea why this movie was made. Was it to tell a compelling story? No. To share a romance? No. To highlight great scenery? No. To showcase the awesome power of a volcano? No. To impress the audience with great acting, beautiful costuming, talented scriptwriters, or coherent action scenes? No, no, no and no. It was an incoherent mess that even Jon Snow, Jack Bauer, & Trinity couldn't save. On a scale of rotten tomatoes, you can at least laugh at the campiness of Plan 9. By the end of Pompeii, we were laughing at the STUPIDITY of lines that weren't meant to be funny and at the poor fool who actually said, "why yes! I'd like to provide financial backing to this endeavor." Horrible in EVERY WAY!! I will never get those 2 hours of my life back. The best part of seeing Pompeii is ragging on it afterward with the people who shared in the torture, in some state of mutual PTSD.Man. I REALLY wanted to love this one!!!

I have been obsessed with Pompeii for a while, and I am a big fan of action movies, so I thought I would absolutely adore Pompeii the movie. There were so many things that were pretty awesome about this movie like the costumes, the scenery and the effects, and then some really bad things. The most horrendous atrocity in this movie was Sutherland's acting. First of all, he doesn't translate to historical pieces to start with (not his fault), so he should have never been casted. Second, his lines were delivered so awkwardly, you could hear the audience's confusion. Any emotion was drained out of every scene he was in. I think if Kiefer Sutherland was not in this movie, I could have overlooked most of the other issues, but he was in this movie, so here we go. Next off, there were many lines that just didn't work in the movie and they were forced into the movie for some odd reason and it was obvious (such as the "Why so serious" line). I also wish they changed the whole opening, rather than show Milo's background, which tired and overused, just introduce him as a gladiator of Pompeii and friends with Atticus. This would leave more time to build relationships within the city and not seem as crazy of reach that he would die for a girl he literally just met (he could have been in love with her for a while). Also, it would have been neat if they used some real life stories to make the movie more well rounded. And my last complaint/note, the audience shouldn't have to yell "Finally" for the action scenes of an action movie. Took too long to get to any real action. The could have had much more interesting gladiator scenes to add to the action, but they were all pretty flat.

This was basically a spin-off and flawed attempt at "Gladiator." The film tries, in vain, to piggyback off the success of Gladiator, while forging a new plot based upon the catastrophe of Pompeii. Unlike Gladiator, the acting and general screen presence of all of the actors, including seasoned ones like Keifer Sutherland and Carrie- Anne Moss, was abysmal. I was really disappointed in Keifer. Normally, his acting is spot-on. In this particular cinematic atrocity, he was really not believable, and his accent was really poorly executed. When every actor's performance in a film sucks, there invariably exists a serious flaw with the casting and script. The characters were not cast as regal or noble, just snotty, sarcastic, and incapable of empathy. The graphics were akin to "The Day After Tomorrow," where the ground surreptitiously collapses in every direction, around a sole character. We get it...he won't escape...blah blah blah. Not recommended.

It's like the Notebook/Titanic, but with 300/Spartacus for men!1) great fight scenes2) brilliant romance3) good art4) horrible acting10/10 no questions asked, I saw it in 3D and was expecting a whole lot worse than I gotThat being said, this is a prime example of how smoking makes a 6/10 movie 10/10If I saw this movie without blazing, I would have been mad at the unrealistic acting, but acting is all fake, and when I was faded, I thought it was hilarious!Do yourself a favor and see this movie, even if it means getting it on DVD instead of going to the theaters for 3D!!

Review title: dreary! avoid even if you're Kit Harington's or disaster movie fan
Review_body: So let me start with saying I'm both: Kit's fan and I do like a good "we're all doomed!" movie. But Pompeii is so cliché, the dialogue and acting so wooden and unconvincing, the scenes so predictable and kitschy it's cringe-worthy, I had trouble sitting through it till the end. All characters are so one dimensional they might as well be portrayed by shadow puppets. There is no humour nor ingenuity but I can live with that, but there is no drama either and that's simply unforgivable for a disaster movie! Avoid. Even if you've been to Pompeii and want to see the city recreated through special effects. They messed this too, all you'll see is one street, very generic to boot. Terrible on all fronts, avoid!!

Watched last night. But oh my God! What the hell that Director was thinking!! Poor story line, piece of crap. Characters of the movie were written poorly. Romance were dull. Now I am wondering how the hell one of my colleague talked so much about it, told me it was very good all the way, and because of his positive interest I watched it yesterday. But bloody hell it was such a waste of time. And I learned one thing, never trust a guy with movie review who doesn't know what he is talking about!! Ending of the movie is absolutely stupid and I was relieved it ended finally and I laughed when it ended. If you want to waste your time, this is your opportunity. To be honest, the visual effects were good, but that doesn't change anything, when you have a poor story; but really, today there are so many movies with great visuals. Most of all they did not really care about the story.

Review title: Poor Frankie Howerd Up Pompeii - This is defo down Pompeii
Review_body: I am giving this 3/10 because of the climatic special effects. This is another case of Hollywood saying balls to the story writing lets blow the budget on the 3D visuals and re-write history, sod everything else.I am still trying to understand who told Kiefer Sutherland it would be a good idea to put on a silly "oooooh matron" voice whilst playing Senator Corvus. I mean the guy sounded like and acted like the B*stard son of the Great Frankie Howerd and Kenneth Williams, whilst, at the same time, trying to act sinister by sucking his upper lip over his teeth every time he opened his mouth. If they ever made Carry on Transylvania he make a great camp Dracula.Then there's the hero - The Celt........WWE anybody? His whole village massacred before him aged 3 or 4. We don't know what happened to him between the ages of 5 and 25......a bit like Jesus. What we do know is he develops Jedi like abilities in horse whispering and sword fighting.He also forgets his "savage" ways and becomes a love sick puppy.Im not sure if the production crew ever went to Pompeii either as it appears that apart from the pyroclastic ass whooping Pompeii received it also took a good kicking from a tsunami.All in all that is 2 hours of my life I will never get back.

After hearing bad reviews about this movie, I wasn't expecting much and I didn't gain much from it either. Kit Harington was the main reason I wanted to watch this as I love him in Game of Thrones but his character in this I found to be a little less convincing. The love story was like any other but there was no real connection between them and the ending was completely expected and came as no surprise. The movie should have made the love story better and concentrated on the volcano more. Overall I gave this a 4 as the story line was good, the a few of the action scenes were decent. The main reason for a 4 is Kit Harington. Without him it would have either been slightly better or a lot worse, depending on the actor. It had all the wrong focuses and I will not be watching it again in a hurry.

I highlight that this is a film because a few people have given this drama a low score on historical inaccuracies, however not once does it claim to be a dramatisation of actual events. Very much like titanic, the main story is a love one but with historical events as a background. The love story was actually quite sweet,and the back story 'pompeii' was full of action and shot in a scarily beautiful way. Yes it may be inaccurate,but so what its a film..if you want accuracy go to the history channel. If you're open minded and able to see passed that then watch the film because its actually pretty good. For those who are game of thrones fans it also has a very own 'jon snow' who not only looks very hot but brings the film to life.

Pompeii the movie. One of the worst movies I have ever seen. Other than Keifer Sutherland (outstanding) and Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje (outstanding) the acting was pathetic. The screenplay was awful and the special effects mediocre.Kit Harrington and Emily Browning's "acting" if that is what you want to call it consisted of blank long-lost love stares into each other's eyes. After the first 50 shots of them staring at each other it got creepy.I only gave it 3 stars because of Keifer Sutherland and Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje.

Review title: Pompeii the home of establishing shots and unnecessarily oiled up men
Review_body: The special effects were good; the acting wasn't too bad but the film itself stupid. I honestly believe that our protagonist Milo (played by Kit Harington) was one of the fastest and luckiest men to ever exist in the history of Pompeii; it could actually be the story of maybe one of the earliest versions of the Flash. Milo is somehow able to travel far distances in a mere matter of minutes, if only his horse Shadowfax (crap I mean Beaures) was as fast. He may also be the luckiest man alive as well! Decisions were made just in time for him to live, the ground stopped breaking and tumbling just before it was enough to make him fall and die, he was somehow not able to be hit by massive flying rocks and not fall from big earthquakes - that somehow are able to destroy building and arena's but not a human being- and yes, in the end he's also luckily able to kill the man who was running away with the girl he fell in love with and risked his life for -after a total amount of probably spending 10 minutes together- and who also killed his family, finally allowing his revenge. This film then ended perfectly, Atticus was able to die a free man after all his hardships, Milo had avenged his family and got to eventually kiss and be with the girl of his dreams right in front of impending doom whilst in his head was wishing "By the old gods and the newI wish I was Daenerys Targaryan". Performance wise Kit Harington was very good, the fight scenes were entertaining and well choreographed, I just feel sorry for Kit having to have his first real Hollywood solo appearance as Milo in this film. He really could have done a lot better. Still we at least know he worked very hard on his appearance, what with all the oil he was wearing, it's in fact pretty hard to miss.In summary, for a film with a very basic story line, simple minded and relatively boring characters, a whole lot of action whilst really knowing the ending anyway (we get reminded enough around every 10 minutes of the film) along with a whole load of beautiful scenery shown by a ridiculous amount of establishing shots so you can say "ooooooh so that's what Pompeii would have looked like" this is the film for you. But, if you want a film with more depth, detailed characters and a much more thought out storyline, look for the film Gladiator, I think Maximus Decimus Meridius would be slightly insulted and disappointed with this film. I mean seriously "are you not entertained?"

This film is a poor copy of Gladiator with Russell Crowe, and Joaquin Phoenix. Here's and actor comparison Gladiator vs Pompeii:Russell Crowe = Kit Harrington (John Snow from Game of Thrones) - Joaquin Phoenix = Kiefer Sutherland - Oliver Reed = Joe PingueJust as the actors don't hold a candle to those in Gladiator, the fight scenes are a blow by blow replica - albeit on a smaller budget. They also copy key script lines from Gladiator but John Snow can't deliver them like Russell Crowe.At least we can all agree that we think Kiefer Sutherland is an idiot, and so we can hate the bad guy, just as we rallied against Joaquin Phoenix in Gladiator.Because the acting is so wooden, they had to add in a bunch of special effects about earthquakes and volcanoes at the end.The only saving grace is they didn't have the music from Gladiator in it.

The trailer itself revealed half of the story. Gimmicky, too many 3D effects and total fiction. The adaptation too seems totally out of place and poor in my opinion. Why would you show a love story in the middle of a historical catastrophe? Anyway, thought I might still give it a try but then its just a mediocre movie. In fact, I would have rather enjoyed more a historical account of some families who managed to escape the volcano than some fiction romance, to be quite honest.The story too is utterly shallow. It was the usual 'oppressed gladiator meets Roman lady' romance with every Roman shown as being evil and monstrous. Which makes it even more boring. For some reason, there are too many directors who don't realize that they make a bad movie when too many stereotypes are shown off. There's just too much 'I hate you and now I kill you' stuff in a totally goofy setting. The fighting is good which actually prompts me that this could have been a better movie like Russell Crowe's if all the goofy stuff wasn't included!

When I saw that Kit Harington ( Jon Snow in Game of Thrones ) was going to be in this I immediately had to go see it! What I saw however was somewhat disappointing.I know the movie is based on the disaster at Pompeii but I found the plot a little generic and the screen writing made the actors sound really wooden.The action scenes, visual effects and delicious eye candy that is Kit Harington made up a little for the very stiff acting and predictable plot but still it could've been way better had they developed the plot and characters more!

I am funny this way - sometimes I love movies because of the action and the entertainment and sometimes I dislike movies of the same reason. When you name or base a movie of an event that is of interest to me and the world with the interest itself, such as "Titanic" or in this case, "Pompeii" you expect to see a bit of a disaster. In a way, both Titanic and Pompeii might as well have been a documentary from National Geographic simply because we want to know more about the disasters and nothing else. I just don't care about Rose and Jack and their Romeo and Julia-like love for each other and in Pompeii, I don't care about a love story that is made up in a Hollywood-esque way. My interest lies in the title of the movie and nothing else. Of course this means that up till 1:10 of the movie I am playing with my mobile phone, tweeting, reading news and with a quarter of an eye watching what's happening on the screen. I have no interest what so ever in love stories and political feuds - I am here to see the volcano erupt and to see how "they" managed to capture the horror of the event. Which means I could easily fast-forward an hour because that's when the "action" starts. Some might now think of me as a dull and boring movie enthusiast that isn't even worthy of reviewing a movie like this one. So be it. And perhaps a NG documentary would have suited me better, since I don't care about made-up love stories that are more or less invented for the Hollywood feel of it all. Okay, there is a build-up to get to know the main characters and you might get emotional and close to them in a typical Hollywood way, but focusing on this when you name a movie after one of the world's most known disasters, is fooling your audience. And at some point I am sick and tired of this. Picturing an event known for certain things, should focus on them, nothing else. So yes, I might go to National Geographic or Discovery Channel next time to get the real idea of what happened. Because this is just pathetic. But that's what you are dealing with when wanting to base a movie on an actual event - stay true to the known events or make up you own story.I prefer the first.

I find this movie struggles with its identity, it starts out as what looks like a forbidden love between an aristocrats daughter and a down trodden gladiator. This plot line in itself was a movie, and I was finding the love story very engaging and the battles reminded me of an episode of Spartacus. About 45mins in, one wonders why this movie is even called Pompeii as it is rattling along nicely without any involvement from the volcano looming in the background.Just as this little sub-movie reaches its climax, the director decides it's time he introduces the main character.
