This is the point where to movie looses me, it goes from good story telling and a nice amount of suspense to a six year old throwing a tantrum and destroying everything in its path. The explosions are ludicrous, the tidal wave doesn't even make sense, I think the director got volcano confused with earthquake but worst of all the protagonists die. I am not always for a happy ending, but the story was so diluted by the time they actually die that the sadness of it all was lost in the stupidity the preceded it and I was just glad it had all come to and end.If you've got nothing better to do and you're all out of good movies to watch, then give this a go. Or just watch the first 45mins and treat it as a pilot episode to a TV show that never aired.Stars **

I had high expectations from this movie so overall it was a slight disappointment. Amazing history of ancient Pompeii is overshadowed by a cliché love story. Nevertheless,for those who like cliché love stories this one is worth watching. 3D and sound effects are very strong and have a decent quality. The ending is expected and a bit predictable,but emotional. Acting is solid even though there are some obvious mistakes. With such a good cast,and such a good budget I expected a lot more.Kit Harington's dashing appearance covers his pale acting while Emily Browning's acting has surely improved.All in all,it's a good movie but nothing more than that.

Review title: Why DID I like this film?
Review_body: Many people are out there saying it's "historically inaccurate", it's "a remade of gladiator WITH A VOLCANO!" and a very cliché film. but I'm saying it is a really good movie on it's own, considering that this IS A DISASTER MOVIE. And in many aspects this is better than 2012, Volcano, or other movies like these. For starters, there is an actual plot to the movie before the volcano erupts. Other things I liked:The gladiatorial theme is well presented. You can see people who hate being a gladiator, people who are just waiting for their freedom, people who believe they are gods in the arena, and so on, and you can watch how the majority of Romans loved these shows, but some didn't. You can make yourself an idea of the weather of that theme.The romance is believable. I mean, it happens very fast, but it's not Disney's "Real Love" They are just two people who LIKE each other caught in the massive chaos of a volcano, not much more. the special effects are plain awesome! Not only the gigantic explosion and lava bombs, and tsunamis. Also the small things, like the views of the city in the background, and the aerial shots.The city was amazing. People complain "Pompeii is not a port city" Well, actually it WAS, but the eruption changed the shape of the coastline. And the fact that THAT city shown in the movie WAS Pompeii. They actually shoot in place and then recreated the city out of the remainings using CGI. So the grid shape, the walls and everything is in place just as it was 2000 years ago. Archaeologists have in fact praised the director for his recreation of the citythe volcano. It's the star of the movie without a doubt. It seems to have almost a personality. The way the eruption happened was very close to what actually happened. Some artistic liberties were made for the sake of entertaining. You won't be seeing any clichéd lava river because Mount Vesubius doesn't work that way.The ending. It was amazing. I can't spoil it for you, but making it in any other way would have damaged the quality of the film.The acting. It was really good for what I was expecting. Milo surprised me a lot, because I could really believe him as a lead man. The girl also. She seemed so plain in photos, but once the movie started I could say she nailed the part perfectly and was by no means just "miss fanservice", as girls in these kinds of movies tend to be. The real surprise was Atticus. The actor totally stealed the movie for himself in every scene, something that was perfect for an invicted champion in the peak of his gladiatorial career.What didn't I like? The fact that the other famous city in the vicinity of Vesubius(Herculaeum, I think it's called) wasn't showed in the aerial shots. I mean, obviously the movie would be to complicated if we include it in the plot, but an aerial cameo of this other city would have been a fine addition to the movie, and would have improved the accuracy of it.

Review title: Predictable but Very Good Special Effects
Review_body: Watched this movie on my Computer Screen, it was an awesome experience, but story was too plain and predictable, even a 5 year kid can tell you that what is going to happen in the next scene.Nothing new, we have seen this type of story in hundreds of movies. Period movies are so common now a days that you may find it really boring, there were Politics, Dialogs, Horses, Sword fights(Not so impressive), beautiful dresses(very common), Princess (who is fallen for a slave), a gladiator (doesn't look like one), a Villain etc The whole idea was the movies to show you how Pompeii city destroyed by the Volcano Eruption, they used really talented and great VFX team to achieve that, it was really amazingly done on that part. I am giving my ratings for it's VFX team only else there is nothing you can praise for.Watch this movie only for nicely crafted special effect scenes, don't expect anything from the story.Note: Obviously English is not my first Language.

Pompeii is being called another Titanic movie and rightfully so. Both movies contain the same formula of lets take a real life historical human tragedy and put Romeo and Juliet in it. It even contains a lot of the same characters. The only difference between the two films is that one is far more superior to the other. I'm talking of course about Titanic. Titanic did it right where Pompeii just did it wrong.Pompeii annoyed me to tears. My whole experience in the theater was me rolling my eyes and groaning inwardly. Poorly developed love story, poorly developed characters that behave stupidly, and a climax that was just meh. Im going to make some comparisons of my experience watching Titanic for the first time to my experience of watching Pompeii. I went in to both movies looking forward to the epic climax; for Titanic it was the iceberg and the ship sinking and in Pompeii it was the eruption of Mt. Vesuvius. Both had a love story but what Titanic did right and what Pompeii failed to do is get me invested. The purpose of the romance in Titanic was to make you care and to get you emotionally involved so that by the time tragedy happens you're concerned and you hope they survive. In Pompeii we have our lovers Milo (Kit Harrington) and Cassia (Emily Browning) who are brought together by the fact that Milo is an enslaved Celtic gladiator who's out for vengeance against the man who killed his family and did I mention he's a horse whisperer. Seriously, Cassia likes Milo because the first time she met him he took a dying horse out of his misery by breaking its neck and the next time they see each other he's taming one and taking her on a magic carpet ride.sorry, a beautiful moonlit horse ride that was short lived and lasted a whole 5 minutes. Then it's oh my god I love him. Two scenes people! With very little exchange of dialog! I mean their whole screen time together is at least ten minutes tops. And we're supposed to believe that these two are in love? Hell they don't even kiss until the end of the film (which I will get to in a moment). I don't think these two even knew each other's name. I didn't care about them and I didn't care about their "love". Titanic made me care, I was concerned, I was invested so invested that I forgot that I was on the Titanic and everyone was going to die. Pompeii just had me wishing the volcano would hurry up and explode. Another thing that pisses me off about this film is the movie mustache twirling bad guy Corvus (Kiefer Sutherland) who's purpose is quite clear. He even has an evil henchmen named Proculus. Corvus' job job is to make you hate him until he gets whats coming to him in the end. Corvus wants to marry Cassia but Cassia doesn't want to marry him cliché. Now when Mt. Vesuvius erupts things start to get stupid. All hell is breaking loose people are running for their lives Pompeii is being destroyed you would think everyone's biggest concern is to get the hell out of there right? Wrong. Instead we have Corvus playing the villain for the sake of staying the villain by killing innocent people, kidnapping Cassia in a chariot forcing Milo to ride after him on horseback seriously I'm surprised he didn't let out an evil laugh as this was going on. The fact that the whole world was coming apart around him was like an afterthought and not of the least bit of a concern. Secondly we have this fight between the slave Atticus (Adewale Akkinouye-Agbaje) and Corvus's henchmen Proculus which was totally uncalled for because HELLO the city is being destroyed by a volcano get the hell out who cares about this fight?! As for the climax, it happened kind of fast and I was kind of rooting for the volcano.Watching all the death and destruction didn't faze me in the least. If proper time had been devoted to the audience getting to know these characters I probably would've felt more sympathetic . I will say this though, the build up to the volcano erupting was really nice, the massive quakes, the rumbling, the animals acting weird. The foreshadowing and the rising tension of the upcoming danger really gets you excited for what's coming. It almost kind of teases you making you ask "oh no is this it is it going to happen now." I will give the movie that much credit. The final shot of the lovers embracing in a kiss as a giant ash cloud swallows them was visually appealing however it failed to leave an emotional impact because again I don't care about them. Think about Titanic when Jack died that really struck home with a lot of people because the audience cared about them and wanted them both to get out of there alive. We knew who these people were, we cared about their relationship therefore there was a greater impact. In Pompeii there was no time to develop the story. The director could have even showed us the lives of some of the citizens just so we could feel something! All in all was it a good movie? Sadly not really,no. I really wanted it to be. It is watchable just don't go expecting something spectacular better yet just wait for the Netflix release.

Review title: Not exactly good, nor as bad as most people would say
Review_body: I think most peoples and my main issue with the film is the subject matter. Everyone has seen the events of pompeii on screen many times and hence the plot and ending are no surprise, so we must be entertained by only the visuals and some sort of love story. The acting and directing were mostly fine. Kit Harrington and Emily Browning were passable and Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje put in a noteworthy performance. The visuals and effects were by far the best aspect and kept the film very watchable and enjoyable to an extent throughout. The script was poor and most of the usual disaster movie clichés appeared at some point or other but in no way was it as awful as in say, 2012. Overall its probably not something to see at the cinema, but probably worth a watch on DVD or TV at some point. 5/10

Review title: They should've just called it Gladiatanic. Obviously.
Review_body: This film is either a 1 out of 10. Or a 10. And I can't decide which.Firstly, for those people comparing it to Titanic and Gladiator... That's one of the main problems with this film. Or it is the stroke of genius that lifts this film out of obscurity.I wasn't primed with the Gladiator/Titanic idea before watching Pompeii, I hadn't read any reviews. But I soon thought of those two films as more likely source material for Pompeii than the writings of Pliny the Younger. And I can now see that I am not alone.Hence I shall now refer to this film as Gladiatanic.Now, I'm not going to be overly-critical of Gladiatanic for its historical inaccuracies. Those are merely superficial issues which arise from trying to put the historical gloss on what is a new and exciting cross-breed of film.The main problem is that if you were to take the film Gladiator and then try to crowbar in a love story and disaster, a la Titanic, there would just be too much going on unless you have a veritable genius in charge of script.I don't know why I'm talking about this idea hypothetically. That is actually what they've done here.Bad acting? Not really. The actors do remarkably well portraying completely unrealistic characters. I started to feel a bit sorry for them as they tried to remember at any given second whether they were pursuing revenge, love, freedom or survival.Good effects? Yeah, but they never feel realistic or perilous. But that may be because I couldn't bring myself to care about the main characters. I did try to care, I promise. But the poor sods never felt like anything other than meaningless puppets designed to act in whatever way required to bring about their ultimate fates.Gladiatanic does almost conjure up some really good imagery. Almost. Like the bit with a couple of bodies being slowly covered in ash. But it felt far too contrived to hit home.Bad script then? Well, perhaps. But, again, the problem is that there is simply too much going on and when you stop and think about any one thing, it seems just far too convenient for the purpose of the plot.I mean, take the scenes where Milo and Atticus become friends. The script isn't awful. But the whole time I'm wondering why on earth these two are bunking together when they are supposed to be fighting to the death the very next day.Yes, everything in movies is contrived. And you don't go to watch boring stories. So suspension of disbelief is not something I am incapable of. But there's only so much I can take and that example is a pretty small one.The main example of this overt contrivance is the main love triangle.He's a slave and she's a citizen who meet through a chance encounter? OK. Some senator from Rome is interested in her too? No problem. That senator happens to have murdered the slaves parents a long time ago in a foreign country? Erm, that's a bit convenient. And then the slave happens to annoy the senator without realising that the senator was the person who murdered his parents? Talk about unlucky...So, yeah, you start to notice the little things.The other thing about that triangle is the antagonism between Milo and Corvus. Does Milo act for revenge or love? It's never really clear - it is both in varying measure according to who is watching Gladiatanic. But it's not totally for love. And it's not totally for revenge.It's for lovenge.Gladiatanic is ultimately a very confused film, as you might expect it to be. I suspect it's because they've tried to please as many demographics as possible.And perhaps, being cynical, it works in that respect. This lovenge story has enough love to please those who want romance and enough revenge for those who want action. But you have to really really want it to be one of those things and not the other.And, quite frankly, it could easily be neither.I don't think Milo was that bothered about saving Cassia. I don't think he was that bothered about killing Corvus.And in the end it shows (SPOILER) 'cos he didn't actually do either.It's not surprising I'm confused about this film and what score to give it. As Pompeii, a love and revenge disaster action drama, it failed at the concept stage. For me, at least.As Gladiatanic, an existential lovenge story about the inability of men to multitask, it is an unmitigated triumph.

The most violent eruption of Vesuvius has inspired many depictions of the destruction of Pompeii and Herculaneum. There are plenty of stories to be told in this event, the volcano undermines the Romans belief of their infallibility, and the eruption is spectacular.However, instead of focusing director Paul W.S. Anderson instead assembles a collection of television actors (Kit Harrington from Game of Thrones, Kiefer Sutherland from 24 and Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje from Lost) to play out a dumbed down version of Gladiator.The first half of the film is desperately contrived; a slave witnesses his family killed by Romans, and years later encounters the man responsible in the arena of Pompeii. The derivative plot could be forgiven if the fight scenes were up to much, but they are edited so frenetically that it's impossible to keep track of what's going on. Even the death of one character in the arena is identical to that of the emperor's in Gladiator.On the plus side, the eruption itself is impressively handled, even if the 3D is not. The film is at most enjoyable when Vesuvius is bombarding Pompeii with huge igneous chunks of rock or smothering it with a pyroclastic surge. The tidal wave that sweeps back escaping ships is less convincing (particularly as no ships were discovered in the ruins).Spectacular though the eruption is, there is fatal lack of energy and storytelling, leaving Pompeii as a sword-and-sandals adventure is little more than a guilty pleasure.

Review title: Meh is how I feel about this film
Review_body: It wasn't the greatest of movies nor was it the worst. To be perfectly honest the film barely made an impression on me; the plot line seemed somewhat confused not to mention unbelievable (I mean who really can hope to out run a volcano). Although I must admit that the action packed fight scenes and some occasional shots of perfectly sculptured abdominals definitely compensated for the obvious flaws.If you remove the twenty or so minutes of actual fighting within the film, what you're left with is about a hundred minutes of what could essential be a fairytale. Though the entire thing was littered with improbable scenarios, I found that there were three scenes so ludicrous that I could not help but laugh.Read the full rant I did on this film, clearly stipulating why this film failed to impress me. http://thatgirlreadallaboutit.blogspot.co.uk/2014/05/pompeii_7.html

Review title: Let's bury this under tons of magma.
Review_body: How much can be realistic a love story between a slave and a young roman patrician girl? Well, this is not the point. We are going to see a motion picture and the plot could also be something not so original. But falling in love because our hero kills a wounded horse this is just ridiculous. This gave me the strong suspect the screenplay was very poorly scripted. As I saw the first end credit all my suspect were gone and I was sure about that. Unfortunately, the screenplay is not the worst thing in this movie. Kit Harington is totally unfit for the role of a gladiator. The trainer and the nutritionist did their job but his lack of charisma, his expressionless eyes are unable to captivate the spectator. Better performance for Emily Browning but nothing special. With a screenplay like that, she act at the best she can and is the only (with Carrie-Ann Moss) I could save among this mess. The other main character is played by Kiefer Sutherland. Nothing special to say about him. He act but seems unfit to the role. He also sunk within the screenplay. CGI effects are the best part of the movie but I'm not taking it into consideration because they add nothing to the story.With a better plot, better dialogs and with a different ending, this movie could have been enjoyable... but in the projection room, everyone was waiting the Vesuvio to erupt, bury this movie and go home.

God where do you start with this movie? Its bad, painfully bad! My biggest complaint with it was the performances and the badly written characters. As a fan of Game Of Thrones i think Kit Harington's character John Snow is ruined for me for ever. It left me thinking he is the type of actor who needs to be surrounded by other great actors to look half decent. He is not totally to blame for his performance. It is neigh on impossible to ask an actor to show real emotion if there is nothing for them to connect with in their characters. And there is nothing! The dialog is utterly terrible. I myself tried writing scripts years ago and looking back on them they were just montages of all the most clichéd and obvious lines from movies i remembered off the top of my head. This movie does no better than me. Seriously! Its so bad it was funny then not funny then funny again finally i settled on just wincing and clenching my arse cheeks every 2nd line. All this while waiting for the bloody thing to erupt. Which finally does one hour into the movie. From there its just OK. But they could have given the Volcano a bit more personality. Other disaster films have managed to do it. But here it is very detached bar the odd tremor. They could have gone into the volcano to show it happening beneath the surface, it would have added to the suspense. At the end of the movie i had to take a shower, not to wash off the ash but the stench of Hollywood garbage. The ratio of bad blockbusters to good ones these days is a joke given the money invested and the price of a ticket. Give this movie a wide berth and rent Gladiator and Independence Day instead you'll have a much better time.

I am not going to write about how the directors utterly destroyed historical facts etc. I am only disappointed because i feel that i was deceived by the trailer. When i watched the trailer i thought that this could be a historically based gladiator based with really cool cinematic effects. What i actually got in the movie was probably the worst love story since Star Wars Episode 2. Totally one dimensional characters and dialogues. Also from the trailer i did not anticipate that the entire film was going to revolve around this pathetic love story. Also, i hate it when films are totally unrealistic. I mean why did they escape on a horse (long before the eruption) if the had no intention to actually run away. No purpose scene which made me want to leave from the theatre that second. Directors....you deceived me.

The problem i find today is that i am very hard to please with movies due to everything copying each other in some way. I went in to watch this movie with a sceptical mind but after the end credits were rolling i was left with a huge smile and felt fulfilled. I am a huge fan of true stories/factual movies and to top it off i am also a huge fan of Natural Disasters with volcanoes being my favourite. I urge all people that like me enjoy a solid plot, great visuals and just love truth and facts in a movie then watch this. It's easy to see that Kit Harrington is one to watch in the very near future... 10* I will be pre-ordering this when announced

Review title: it is really a good movie
Review_body: i enjoyed the movie. it takes you back to a far away time and place that rally existed. it also show events that really happened. sure a lot of the story had to be made up to give some excitement and reason to care what happens to the people in Pompeii. as for the ending how could it be any different, the volcano did the destruction shown in the movie. the only problem i could have with the movie is the music. i saw it in the theater and kept being pulled out of it in the beginning through the first half every time the theme came to be played. i do not know if anyone else noticed it but it kept remaining me of the movie Poseidon. i hope that more movies are made like this one.

Review title: I think this is a love it or hate kind of movie..
Review_body: Saying that, I didn't particularly fall crazy in love with this film, but I did like it. If you enjoy movies of this type of genre then I say, give it go. Yes, it's titled Pompeii, but don't be fooled into thinking that the movie is based & focuses on Pompeii itself. I do believe that it hardly follows true events of what really happened back when the volcano blew its top, but the storyline they went with & used wasn't that bad.. I thought the special effects did OK & wasn't poorly done & the acting wasn't bad in any way either. I do feel slightly disappointed, they could of really gone to town with the blood, guts & grisly stuff beings as they chose to focus the storyline around fighting, gladiators & more fighting, but the movie lacked any of the sort.

Review title: Got what I came to see
Review_body:
I watched this movie for these reasons:1. Kit Harington's abs
2. Epic volcano
3. Watching slaves fight backI got what I came for and expected nothing else

An entertaining movie. It's a disaster movie but with a real plot outside of the actual disaster. Too predictable though.Some times I was a bit confused while watching POMPE II. Maybe because I have never seen POMPE I.

Review title: What a horrible waste of an hour and a half
Review_body: It was my own fault for expecting a disaster movie with actual characters resembling human beings. This is a badly written romance aimed at 14 year old girls with an active vulcano for a backdrop.

Princess Bride, but played straight, with no self-awareness or humour. "My name is Milo. You killed my father. Prepare to die!".Avoid. The fight scenes are entertaining, but so prolonged that one is taken out of the movie to think "Yeah, but there's no way he'd be able to *keep* fighting for this long".The whole audience (in Paris) laughed at the final utterly ridiculous frames. This was meant to be poignant/heartbreaking - like Titanic. The audience by then just wanted it to be over.There are a few wooden performances, but I suspect it's hard not to be with this script and direction. Even so, Sutherland should be ashamed of his showing in this. He must just have been counting his pay the whole time.Also: 'Milo' the Celt ?? How about using Celtic name?

Anyone who has had their share of bland blockbusters will recognize the signs early on. From the very first scene onward, everything in Pompeii is a cliché. It is obvious the creators simply took a template and filled in the blanks, borrowing heavily from other popular sources. Every character is a trope and fulfills its role to the point where it gets ludicrous. I found myself audibly whispering "bullshit" during one particular scene.The acting is straight up bad for the most part. Some of the supporting actors manage to convey a bit of emotion but there is only so much one can do with the superficial and predictable characters. Poor effort from the leads. It doesn't help either that the costumes look cheap. Many of the padding scenes lack cinematic quality completely.The CG special effects are this movie's only redeeming factor. As unrealistic as most of the events are, they do look convincing. The bits that get you excited when watching the trailer hold up on the big screen.Intuitively I'm giving this movie a 3/10 but depending on the individual that might still seem a bit generous. If you are easily bothered by sub par acting, uninspired storytelling or a ridiculous plot you would do best to avoid Pompeii altogether.

With all the bad movies being made over the last couple of decades, I did enjoy this. That is, until the ending. Being as it was all fictional, the ending could have been much better, especially with special effects. Mostly, I'm picturing a rain shower over the kissing statues and a renewal of life, if you will. It would have left me feeling warm and fuzzy after spending 2.5 hours of my life watching it instead of feeling cheated out of a good ending.

Review title: Pompeii - a blast from the past
Review_body: If you're looking for a movie night out with a strong, complex story with well layered characters and where you build up an emotional bond with those characters, well then you better skip this one.. One the other hand, if you're just looking for a fun and thrilling movie with lots of fighting scenes, the reconstruction and total destruction of an ancient Roman city and outstanding special effects, I would say just sit back and enjoy the spectacle.Of course this movie won't win an Oscar, duh.. we all knew what direction this movie was going to take with Paul WS Anderson in control. But unlike many of his movies, I must say that I enjoyed this one. To go even further, this might be his best film up to now. Yes I know, that's not saying much looking at his repertoire, but comparing to the crap (like the three musketeers) this guy made the past few years, this one is a pearl. Let's start with the cons: 1. the characters aren't worked out well, they're not dull but you can feel there's missing something. 2. The story is far from perfect and we've seen it many times before, but nonetheless it's entertaining. Beware however for a lot of clichés. 3. The destruction of Pompeii depicted in the movie isn't historically correct. The same applies to the depiction of the gladiators, who were in fact not all slaves and above all good gladiators were treated very well. 4. The love story is a bit mealy, but overall didn't bother me that much. The pros: 1. The visuals are truly stunning. The eruption of the volcano, the destruction that it brings, the fights are a feast for the eye. 2. They really did an amazing job reconstructing ancient Pompeii. People who love ancient Roman civilization and architecture will love seeing the reconstruction of this ancient city in her former glory. 3. It's also nice that they put some details of daily life of pompeii in the film, like the insulea, the viae (streets) with stepping stones, the funerary monuments outside the city gates, the termopolia (snack bars) etc. etc. 4. The acting is not the best you'll ever see, but it suffice. Especially Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje does a good job. Kit Harington's acting isn't great, his expression is rather monotonous, but he stood his man in the action scenes. 5. The movie doesn't shy away from violence, which in this case is a good thing. However it's not as brute as I would've wanted it to be for a disaster movie with gladiators..Overall I really enjoyed this movie, just don't expect too much of it and you'll probably have a great time. It is what it is, a fun popcorn- movie, not more but also not less. I normally would give this movie a 6/10, but because I have a weakness for historical movies I'll rate Pompeii with a solid 7.7/10 ~ Review by GlenBender

Review title: I loved it, even if others didn't.
Review_body: A lot of reviews on here point out the mistakes and the clichés and the poor acting, but I loved every part of it.... well, all except two things. One, Keifer Sutherland played a perfect bad guy, but he tried way to hard to have an accent and it didn't sound right.. Two, I wish Milo and Cassia could've gotten a little more time together. I hate crappy endings, even if I knew no one would survive in this movie... But to continue, I'm sure there were a lot of problems with this movie, but I loved every minute of it, and wished it was longer... I really didn't want Atticus to die, but as I said, no one would, obviously, make it out alive. That said, I wouldn't mind adding this movie to my collection of favorites...

Pompeii is today's generation Titanic with a beautiful and romantic story. I liked everything about the movie and I would suggest you see it in 3D because the special effects are great. Emily Browning did a great job and looked stunning on the big screen. Usually disaster movies are all about non-stop action but Pompeii throws in some romance combined with "possibly" a true story and makes you wonder if such a romance did really exist when the city was destroyed. I wish the movie was a little bit longer but overall I'm really satisfied and can't wait to own it on blue ray. For everyone who didn't like the movie I would suggest that you look at this movie from a historical perspective because it's an eye opener. Watching how the city is destroyed and what people went through during that catastrophic event is reliving a part of that ancient history.

Review title: TERRIBLE doesn't even begin to describe this
Review_body: This was by far the worst movie I have ever seen! The ONLY thing the movie had in common with ACTUAL events was that there was a volcano that erupted... and people died... THAT'S IT! TERRIBLE! Hollywood filled this movie with nothing but pointless drama and was terribly directed and even worse written with lines and actions from the characters that didn't even begin to make logical sense... Wouldn't the roman politician have bribed her with marriage? *shakes head* Not that that part even came close to belonging in the film at all! Even the special effect of the volcano erupting was incorrect half the time! I could have written this better, had character development here and there of TOWNSFOLK and every day citizens, make you attached to them, then show the turmoil they went through trying to escape making you care about them rather than: Let's put a love story in with lame ass politics cross with gladiator fights and maybe then show 1/4 of the movie or less with the volcano erupting while continuing the pointless love triangle where the bad guy doesn't give up... THERE'S A VOLCANO ERUPTING PEOPLE.... RUN!!!!! *rolls eyes* Worst movie I've ever seen!

This movie is something I expected would be a huge disaster film from almost the start of the movie like other volcano disaster movies have been that we have seen, such as Volcano with Tommy Lee Jones and Dante's Peak with Pierce Brosnan. But instead of that this movie actually starts out pretty slow and was a bit boring, I was not really drawn into the story that much by the actors. Once the action does really ramp up with the volcano starting to erupt there were a lot of great visuals but this movie still was not anything special. It's only worth seeing on the big screen if you really like disaster effects etc. The romance story is just all right.

Going and and still knowing through historical facts how this movie was going to end, I still enjoyed it. It had everything Action, Romance, Drama, and Suspense in someways. I chose not to go and see this movie in theaters and I am kinda glad I waited for it to come out on DVD. This movie reminded me of a few other movies that I got the impression they chose to get there inspiration for, I saw Gladiator, I saw a little of the Notebook, I say a little of Titanic, yet I still enjoyed this movie greatly. I did not give this movie a 10 because this movie could have been better, I think that they could have given the story a little more actions scenes, and a few more scene of romance. Notice how I am trying to be careful not to give anything away. If I had to narrow down all of the scenes to pick one that I would call my favorite I would have to say with out spoiling it the scene that in small parts reminded me of a scene in Star Wars Episode II, when you see it you might see what mean.

Review title: Mediocre story and representation of a natural disaster
Review_body: Serviceable storyline between two average characters around good recreation of a natural disaster during an ancient time that could be better represented and fleshed out. The background of characters and storyline is as simple as it can be to let viewers be familiar with the subdued and monotone tone throughout the movie. The movie rest on its laurels for far too long in certain parts, without much of a surprise and highlights to look forward to and leaving the viewers to wait for the movie to come to its conclusion that can already be seen coming from miles away. As far as the special effects are concerned, there are parts that were done well while others left a lot to be desired. The cinematography are also inconsistent with beautiful panoramic shots and blurry action shots. Based on the director's previous works, it would not come as a surprise. It's a serviceable B-movie grade viewing experience and would not justify a higher praise than that. Watch it just for a nice break from your life. Turn off your mind and enjoy the visuals. Believe me, there's not much to digest intelligence-wise. It's a middle-of-the-road movie for me.

This is my first review on IMDb and I hope this one is well readable despite me not being a native speaker. I've recently watched the movie without knowing what I was about to see, so I could enjoy it without expectations of any sort - despite the fact that this movie should somehow be related to the city of Pompeji. Overall the movie did quite deliver in some ways, but surely not all. The room for character development is already restricted by the fact that the main story part of the movie seems to take place in something that feels like 24 hours or less. While the leadership of Pompeji, the Gladiators and the soldiers of Rome are portrayed quite detailed (I especially like the costumes, which are looking really great!), there is basically no interaction between any of them and the citizens of Pompeji. I would have loved to see some details about their everyday life, how they feel towards the main character. Of course this is a crossover between a medieval drama and a disaster movie, but it wouldn't have hurt to give some more of those many victims a face. The fights seem to be well executed and directed, although the main characters seem a bit overpowered compared to Roman soldiers. By itself the disaster delivered some great scenes - of course it doesn't reprise the original volcanic eruption of Pompeji which would possibly not result in much suspense. They added some more elements which surely weren't happening to Pompeji (to those interested in: it seems like they added up the 1755 Lisbon earthquake to the volcanic eruption of Pompeji).All in all this movie was diverting, but maybe not worth watching a second or third time in the near future. Acting was somewhere between mediocre and decent at average with nobody really excelling. VFX was also OK for a production that size. Nothing too bad, but nothing really special. However, 3D effects were a bitter better than the average 3D effects. I can't say anything about the score, which basically means that it was neither good nor bad. So not as bad as some reviews make it look like, but certainly not a new genre legend.Unfortunately I also have to state that the ending which was meant to be dramatic and epic only worked out as totally cheesy.

I knew that I wanted to write a review for this movie, although I honestly didn't know what to make of it. I guess your opinion of this movie will be all about perspective. This movie is for those of you who like pretty things. The scenery is pretty (gorgeous even). The actors are pretty (Oh my, Mr. Harington!). The costumes are pretty. The locations are pretty. The special effects are pretty. The love cliché is pretty.And despite all these facts everybody must of course know: It's historically inaccurate. It's Gladiator meets Titanic. It's an impossible cliché.But it's so pretty!

if you want clichés aplenty, people outrunning tidal waves, out galloping lava flow, a respite from hurling molten rocks so our gallant heroes recreate the Errol Flynn sword fight on convenient debris clean stairs, this is for you. Some of the worst acting I've seen, so bad thought i'd begin writing film reviews, Emily Browning with golf ball cheekbones and a botox look of horror stares upon Mount Mordor, or whatever it was after we have put up with an hour of the cheesiest Kiera knightley-esque diction with staccato and often monotone recital. Kiefer Sutherland with ill fitting teeth makes you wonder if its actually Eddie Izzard playing the role who wisely erased his name from the face of the credits. Jon Snow, that's Kit Harrington tries to put some effort into it but fails miserably when allied with Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje who is so wooden he shouldn't have been called Atticus, when Attic would do.It's not just a bad film, its an analogy for Hollywood, it's overblown tripe. If you want more enjoyment in 3D, throw a banger into a box of fireworks and run.

I don't get all of the reviewers acting like they were expecting some sort of cinematic masterpiece from a disaster movie.
Yes, it's cheesy and the characters aren't all that well developed, but, for what it is, the acting is solid. There is a plot, even if it is not original or perfectly accurate. The special effects are really well done. I was perfectly entertained. If you went into watching this movie thinking you were going to get anything more than what they give you, it's your own fault.
If you're bored and need to kill an hour and a half, you could do worse than watching this. Sure it's sorta bad, but bad like a disaster movie is supposed to be. I enjoy decent cheese from time to time.

Review title: one of best movies in years! do not miss it
Review_body: I don't know why some reviwers here gave this movie so bad comments. Well, it is hard to top a movie like Gladiator and maybe no movie will ever do. However, I watched Pompeii after visiting the actual Pompeii in Italy and developing an interest in the cities history and romans. The movie Pompeii gives you a solid history lesson, mixed in a dramatic love story. The movie is watchable and I would rate it as a solid 6.

Paul W. S. Anderson, I really hate you.I have seen this movie last winter and oh my god what did I just watch? First off, who the hell thought it would be a good idea to have Paul W. S. Anderson as the director for Pompeii. He deserves to be fired.I don't see him as the director. I see Guillermo del Toro as the director for this movie, but not Paul W. S. Anderson. Now you wonder who the hell is Guillermo del Toro? He is the director that made Pacific Rim and that was awesome.This Pompeii movie was directed by Paul W. S. Anderson. The guy that did the Resident Evil movies, Mortal Kombat, Alien vs Predator, The Three Musketeers, and Soldier. The writer of the script for this movie really needs to be fired as well. Same whoever did the casting.Pompeii is just a combination of Gladiator, Titanic, Dante's Peak, Volcano, 2012, The Legend of Hercules, 10,000 BC, Romeo and Juliet, and may I need to go any further? Now that I made that list, let me give you a few minutes to let that sink in.Pompeii is basically about this slave turned Gladiator who was taken to Pompeii to fight. He kills Babydoll's horse to put it out of it's misery and she gets turned on by it. Does that make sense to you? Anyway, he befriends a gladiator named Atticus. This senator came to Pompeii to take control of the city and wants to marry Babydoll. Why the heck Kiefer Sutherland was cast as the Senator? He is not British nor he acts Roman. There were too many plots to follow. The characters are not interesting and boring. Kit Harrington acts just like Kristen Stewart. Imagine Bella Swan from the Twilight movies as a man. Disturbing right? Basically, Paul W. S. Anderson decided to cast very good actors and made them acted like there are just there for appearance. Really? No one was acting, that was how bad this was. The dialog was so bad that I wanted to vomit in the movie theater. Maybe vomit on Paul W. S. Anderson's shoes and see how he likes it.I was waiting for that volcano to blew up and destroy everything. And it did.This movie is 100 percent inaccurate. Here are my reasons, the eruption happened at 1pm at 79 AD; the eruption blanket the sky with ash and rained down tons of pumice; there were no volcanic bombs shooting out of the sky; most of the people were poisoned to death by the toxic gas from the pyroclastic flows at the other sides of the volcano; some people stayed thinking that it would be over within an hour; there were no tsumanies that destroyed the harbor of Pompeii; no one can survive a pyroclastic flow because it has an average temperature of 2000 degrees Fahrenheit; the bodies had been buried and their tissues rotted away leaving casts for archeologists to pour in plaster and dig them out and they are not mummies. I have been to Pompeii on my vacation many years ago and I have seen the bodies, I have seen the volcano, and I seen the famous buildings that were in textbooks. I know a lot about Pompeii and volcanoes because I have a BS in Geology and I can tell that movie is very offensive to the Geology world. It also made Dante's Peak a B+ movie. There is a BBC film called Pompeii: The Last Day where they reenacted that day of the eruption and it was based on the actual victims. It is on youtube and it is so much better. Another thing is that the movie has too much CGI, so many plots in one movie, too much 300 fighting, no accuracy, poor director, and there might be poor acting as well.Dante's peak by far is a better volcano disaster movie than Pompeii.I love geology and ancient history. I have been studying and researching that stuff ever since I was 9 years old. I got interested in volcano and Pompeii when I was in 4th grade in school. I have watched a series of documentaries about it. I love learning about it so much that I went to see the city itself and saw that volcano. I love Italy, I love Mt. Vesuvius, I love reading and learning about Pliny the Elder and Younger, I love Ancient History, I love Rome, I love Geology, I love Volcanoes, I love rocks, I LOVE ALL THAT STUFF!!! I just can't believe that Paul W.S. Anderson, the director of the resident evil movie taking one of my favorite stories and turning it into garbage.XXXX YOU PAUL W. S. ANDERSON!!!!!! XXXX YOU!!!!!!!!!!! I want to give this movie a zero out of five! Worse movie I have ever seen! I can't believe that Paul W. S. Anderson made it into a piece of XXXX! Paul W. S. Anderson, GO XXXX YOURSELF!!! Guillermo del Toro, I am begging you! Please make a Pompeii movie and make sure that it is better than Paul W. S. Anderson's Pompeii! If you want to make it based on Pompeii by Robert Harris, go ahead because that book was so much better than the movie! I just finished reading Pompeii by Robert Harris. I thought it was really good! The book did a great job portraying the image and scenery of Pompeii and around the Bay of Naples. I enjoyed it more than the movie. The book showed more of the activity of the volcano before it erupted. This story was more relevant to the event than the movie. That is the kind of movie they should have made.? If there are going to make another Pompeii movie, I know it would be better than Paul W. S. Anderson's.That is all I have to say! 0 out of 5!
Ok, so the story wasn't great and there were a lot of cliché's, but I really liked the way the movie was made: beautiful setting, costumes and cool effects. So overall I really enjoyed this movie!

Review title: A combined Pompeii / Titanic review (to save space)
Review_body: Cassia/Rose yearns for authenticity and rescue from an empty life of unearned privilege. Yet little does she know that the very ship she is sailing on is about to hit a volcano. Her stuck up parents know nothing of love so when happy-go-lucky drifter and gladiator Milo/Jack steps into her life the cataclysm du jour will be the musical score to their passionate rebellion against stultifying normativity. Milo/Jack might be resentful of his third class dungeon but his Irish/Celtic charm finds him ready allies in other minorities despised by the English/Roman autocrats. Milo/Jack proves he is the right man for Cassia/Rose by showing her the beauty of steerage/a field in the moonlight. After climaxing in the best sex ever, the couple can no longer ignore the signs that their parent's stupid world is listing/out-gassing. If they want nooky again they must escape and they call on their new found allies who will die to help them get out (literally). Milo/Jack and Cassia/Rose float away on a door/flaming horse and live happily ever after. Or close enough.
Most of the casting choices make sense but who the hell thought Kiefer Sutherland would make a good Roman senator?? I've liked him in other roles he's had but not this one.

It's not original. The plot was shallow, rushed and copied from everywhere. And despite this, the actors did an outstanding job with their characters (Cassia, her parents, Milo, Atticus) and miraculously brought humanity and believability into the very shallow scripts they were handed. I wish they had tried to hit less tropes, and just done those few tropes really well. With that said, the sword fights were exceptional; all of the gladiator scenes were excellent. The tension buildups and complete destruction from the volcano was excellent too.Spoiler alert: I know its fashionable to kill your protags these days. But after all that cheese, I think the appropriate ending would have been to escape and watch the aftermath from afar. That kissing ash sculpture bit was disappointing.I did however like the movie.

It a fun movie to watch if you like the story of Pompei or you just watch it for Kit Harington. The movie is fun but not really good. There are some parts of the movie that seem like the concept was just copied from another movie. Like the relationship between Cassie and Milo. A slave who fights in an arena and falls in love with the boss's wife. Sounds familiar? Think about Gladiator (2000).
The acting is also not great. Some just say their lines and that's it.
Altogether, the film is entertaining but nothing more.
6/10 for Pompeï

Where to begin with this abysmal movie? Appalling script coupled with some of the worst performances I've seen in film. Not sure how they managed to turn what could have been a brilliant disaster movie into what seemed like the discarded draft pages from the Gladiator script. It's so derivative of Gladiator that it's almost a parody, calling the main character 'The Celt', having the downtrodden princess fall for the protagonist, the Gladiatorial battles and even the token African sidekick. Such a bad movie, not that you'd actually be rooting for such 2 dimensional characters but the ending made you wonder why they bothered with the characters in the first place. Kiefer Sutherland should have been credited as Alan Smithee to save himself the embarrassment of having his name connected to the biggest waste of 100 million dollars of the last ten years. The handling of the project was so inept and so ridiculous, that it wouldn't surprise me if a sequel was in the works.

I went into Pompeii with basically zip expectations, having read the story outline, and all of the negative posts here on IMDb (and elsewhere). In truth, I had decided to give it a pass. Well, what with one thing and another (just couldn't pass up the opportunity to see Vesuvius blow it's top in 3-D).And then it began. And you know what? Much to my surprise it sucked me right in. I ended up enjoying it immensely! I'm not going to do a synopsis of the film, but I am going to mention what I found that was really good about the film (approaching excellence!) And what was not so good (actually - not too many complaints in this department).Good: Opening Credits were moody and ominous, with a quite complex and wonderful score that assisted the action sequences throughout. Opening sequences draw the viewer in. The spare introductory sentences written by Pliny the Younger that appear without voice-over on screen are a nice touch.Cinematography and set design were both top-notch, with the city of Pompeii lovely and all that one might expect a posh coastal resort town to be circa 79 AD.3D added a notch up to the proceedings, without being distracting, in an Avatar kind of way. I only ducked once, when a lava bomb (Google it) seemed to be aimed at my head. Acting was actually quite good, particularly the two leads Kit Harrington and Emily Browning. I don't think I have ever seen Ms. Browning in anything before, and the only thing I had seen Mr. Harrington in was was a single episode (it wasn't for me) of that strange middle-earthy-only-with-sex TV thing that seems to be all the current rage.Kit Harrington. A very big surprise here. When he first appears, all moody and six-packy, one can't help but notice how physically small he is in stature compared to the other characters.Although camera angles and character positioning goes a way to disguise this, it is still fairly obvious that most of the other characters are taller than he is.This really bothered me - for about three seconds or so.It was immediately established that he may be height-challenged, but damn! is he fast on his feet, in a give-no-warning, take-no-prisoners, David-and-Goliath kind of way. And this makes sense: it is actually (at least to me) quite logical that a smaller, leaner person can move faster than a bulked-up Arnold wannabe.Harrington, quite frankly, and quite quickly, made me totally buy that he wasn't someone to mess around with. At all.Although the script does not give him a lot to do, besides grunt and sweat, when he is on screen he is very watchable. Which surprised me again, because in the aforementioned television show he seems mostly just to pout from under his rug (or whatever it is that he wears in that show). In the quiet bits of Pompeii (and there are not many of them) he is, quite frankly, tragic. Even when he smiles (which he doesn't do often here). Tragic, and, somehow, for all of that, with a kind of lost sweetness underneath.Emily Browning pretty much has even less to do here than does Kit Harrington, but she does it well. As the damsel-with-a-backbone-in-distress (why are her parents such wimps, anyway?) she is believable.The other standout is unpronounceable-name guy (Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje) as the frenemy of the Kit Harrington character. He almost stole the show. Almost, but not quite.Special effects are all that I hoped for (no flowing lava, thank goodness - lava didn't flow from Vesuvius) but some really nice to watch pyroclastic flows (Google it).Have read something to the effect that the eruption CGI was "overdone". To that I say: Er. . . what!?! With the possible exception of Krakatoa the 79 A.D. eruption of Vesuvius was perhaps one of the most powerful eruptions that humans have ever witnessed and still lived to write about.The pyroclastic flows and surges, and the ash fall, buried Pompeii and the surrounding countryside (not forgetting Herculaneum) to a depth of about 20 feet or so for the next two thousand years. The two cities were buried so deeply and so completely, that it could not be determined afterwards where they had actually been, and the names of these once vibrant cities were soon forgotten by history.So, yes, it was a bit of a deal. And I'll take all I can get! Not so Good SPOILERS AHEAD.if you haven't seen the film, proceed beyond this point at your own risk.The CGI horses (and people) at the end. During the mad chariot dash through the crumbling city as it is being bombarded by molten chunks of flying magma (I know, I know - magma is not the correct term here, but I like the way it rolls off my tongue - or, in this case, my keyboard) at the end of the film. Why is it that the lobby poster for the film that shows the lip lock is also basically the very last shot in the film - practically the last frame? What's up with that? The embracing lovers turned to stone. Had a flow traveling at 450 mph hit the standing lovers in a field (a pyroclastic flow moves pretty fast) at 1,000 degrees F there likely would have been nothing left.However. . . on second thought. . . the lovers-in-stone was a fitting final image of the film.I like it.And I even misted up a bit at the end.

Review title: Pompeii - Or; How Jon Snow taught Jack Bauer a lesson in retribution and age-appropriate dating
Review_body: Paul WS Anderson (ergo the one who's made a career of forgoing the privacy of homemade tapes and instead realised all his kinky fantasies for mass public viewing by having his missus thrown year on year at increasingly larger and more salivating zombie hordes while modelling the latest in undead-killing underwear and little else - rather than Paul Thomas Anderson who's made a career of trying to be as little like Paul WS Anderson as possible) brings about more mind forgoing white noise, incorporating all his stay-true ingredients just with the Romans stepping in as the historical roots of the Umbrella Corporation and all the fiery-hot punishment a volcano can lash out with to stand in as the end-of-level boss (well not really, but it's a PWSA flick so that line of comparative just demands milking).Given the reality of this situation I should be a bit more respectful in my commentary but if there was any doubt to be had, this isn't a film looking to deliver the respectful rendering of events, though the wiki does state the layout of Pompeii and aspects of the eruption to be quite true to form, if nothing else in the movie, which has been compacted and blown up where needed to put in for the age-old "slave seeking revenge on parent-murdering historical never-do-well apply within: must have 3 facial expressions or less" ad. Opening on gliding close-ups of the resulting Pompeii "casts" of people pretty much sets the bar here; expect PWSA to forgo the brush of subtlety in realising his vision.Enter Jon Snow, or Kit Harrington, playing a horse-whispering Jon Snow in warmer climes. It's not really his fault, there isn't much for him to make a meal out of here as the plot runs a fairly predictable by-the-numbers playbook where the principle demands of him were probably to supply his own oil for greasing up and crunch till the wardrobe department could rely on his abs as a backup in case of an ironing board emergency. Not a dig, he does fine for as they say: great acting is typically defined as convincingly falling for Emily Browning over equestrian executions and escapes. Which he does, just light on the convincingly part. Elsewhere Trinity and Professor Moriarty ruin their reputations by portraying pushover parents who at one point had me thinking this was '10 Things I Hate About You' ilk when Jared Harris plays "is this all your luggage?!" dad. Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje pops up in the gladiator penitentiary and for a moment it seems like he's back in the skin of Adebisi from Oz as he and Kit become frenemies over discourse on how they're going to kill each other, comparing weaknesses, sidestepping shanks and playing at 'winner takes nought, loser gets eviscerated 're-enactment roleplay. Basically the whole mechanics of this film requires no dialogue, it works just as well as a silent movie as you know what everyone's going to do and the who's and when's of character dispatch as the "plot" tired of them and how the trivial nuisance of freshly absent skin at the lash of a whip won't deter Kit. Nah, just pour a bit of merlot on it, right as rain.All that said, I didn't hate this film. It's a 'noisy without saying ought', textbook plotted, tomb pillaging bugger of a film but in that it is an okay brainless actioner.......plus there's Jack.Yes, in some seemingly bizarre casting that had me befuddled as to whether this was complete misstep or magic, Kiefer Sutherland puts in a turn as the nasty, oddly kinda camp, wrong-un that is Senator Corvus. I think it's the weight of being so instantly recognisable for one specific role that had me confused with his portrayal here that the gut reaction is "why Kiefer?! Why?!". However by the end it was pretty much his film through being an unrelenting bar steward in that role and getting gleefully grimy in that guise. This is the real reason Bauer feels the need to keep righting the wrongs and martyring himself up every few years: guilt of the ancestors.

Wow. Seriously, just an all-around bad film. I stumbled on it while home sick with the flu. 104 minutes of my life I'm never getting back.It's poorly acted and the characters leave you indifferent. Kiefer Sutherland's momentary lapses into Jack Bauer are just awkward.The only redeeming quality of the film? EVERYONE DIES!!!!!

Review title: This Movie Did Not Upset Me
Review_body: I'm just in disbelief that it actually exists.I'll never understand why someone would make a film that 1) Is so dumbed down a 6 year old can easily follow it, 2) Is so dumbed down anyone over 11 will be insulted by it, yet 3) includes enough violence that you have to be 13 or older just to be allowed to watch it. What could possibly be going through the minds of the filmmakers?I'm well aware that sometimes movies are produced to capitalize on whatever is popular at the time. In this case, Kit Harrington is popular, period pieces are popular, especially those that include swords and armor, and gladiators are popular. And when it's one of those kinds of movies, the entire production process will be as rushed as possible because doing that saves money, and in the case of movies like those, making money is the ONLY thing that matters.But that's not what happened here. There simply isn't a point to making a film which has small children as its target audience, when small children aren't legally allowed to view it. It's completely possible to rush a film and churn out a stinker without dumbing it all the way down for the absolute lowest conceivable common denominator. That is something that is done intentionally.So it's not just a matter of poor execution, whether forced or otherwise. It's a mystery that will never be solved.

The history of Pompeii and its fate was completely ignored (I have visited Pompeii myself) - the tsunami scene was only one of the non sense historical goofs. The movie end is absolutely stupid and I was relieved it finally ended. If you want to waste your time, this is the perfect opportunity.

Review title: Schlocky, Mindless Fun at the Arena
Review_body: Pompeii is wonderfully trashy, a 3D mash-up of all the gladiator movies you've seen and then some. Wearing its inspirations on its sleeve, the film is entirely predictable and derivative, but that doesn't mean that the film itself isn't any fun! Without giving too much away (as though the poster isn't obvious enough), I caught myself enjoying the film, feeling almost a little embarrassed as I chuckled at the melodramatic feel of the enterprise, watching the volcano erupt and wreak havoc as the film tried to make time for youthful love AND revenge. Kiefer Sutherland of 24 (and 1993's cinematic landmark Three Musketeers? No?) fame hams it up as the lead villain, a Roman senator named Corvus who loves to chew scenery and be despicably evil. Jon Sno-er, Kit Harington is perfectly serviceable as the lead, a rebellious and vengeful gladiator known as the Celt. His cheese-grater abs and smoldering looks at the female lead, Emily Browning (as Cassia, daughter of Pompeii's "ruler"), amount to a whole lot of nothing, however, as the film's prospective love story never really gets off the ground, with most of their romance conveyed through extended eye contact and longing looks. The rest of the supporting cast turns in acceptable performances with adequate deliveries of the corny, clichéd dialogue, with Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje as the powerful, axe-wielding gladiator champion Atticus standing out from the rest of the pack. This is shallow fare, and if you go into the film expecting a cinematic wonder on par with, say, a Ben-Hur (OR pick an epic sword and sandals flick you love), you will be quite disappointed at the end result. Director Paul W.S. Anderson, known best for his work on the Resident Evil film franchise, is no maverick, though he seems to be knowingly shooting for a film on par with other guilty pleasures he has created (the first Resident Evil film, for example), striking an old-school feel that ensures he film has no aspirations for higher cinema "glory." The fight scenes are cut up a bit much, with editing ruining some of the impact of brutally quick swordplay making this a mostly bloodless affair, and the mostly humorless narrative never coalesces into a satisfying love story, but if you go into the film with adjusted expectations and leave your history lessons at the door, the blaring score, heated arena battles, and overwhelming, destructive CGI spectacle may just make you smile. It doesn't hurt if you want to see Jack Bauer and a Game of Thrones hero (and a volcano?!) square off either! The rating is: (a decidedly weak) 7!

Review_body: A film for disaster movie junkies, it ticked all our boxes, with one fatal flaw. The story is more about the hero Milo and fellow slave Atticus (played brilliantly by Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje) than the romance it's billed to be, as Milo and his high-born lady barely have any time together. Great special effects (we saw it in 2D, it would have been much better in 3D) but you have to wait for the entirety of the film for them, until then it's mostly bloody fighting. That brings me to the fatal flaw. Keifer Sutherland, playing a Roman tribune with the worst accent I have heard since Hank Azaria's Pharaoh Kahmunrah ruined Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian.

Review title: Exciting, 3D at its best, and a love story to boot!
Review_body: I have waited for this movie since I was a kid after seeing HOUSE OF WAX in 1953 by Andre de Toth. This is truly an "entertainment". Done with a solid creative, structured, and approachable level. The 3D cinematography is at once expansive and at the same time beautifully intimate in its close-ups. it is truly one of the finest 3D action films I have experienced. The script kept me engaged throughout, with good character development and story pacing. The music score is thrilling. The sound fx and surround mixing exceptional. Well timed were surround fx with negative parallax (off screen) 3D effects. I will see this film again at the XD Cinema in Monterey California. Their presentation was exceptional. Highly recommended for families.

Review title: Unfortunately, I preferred Frankie Howerd's Up Pompeii (MINOR SPOILERS)
Review_body: I must admit there are plenty of flaws with the movie and it does lack some of the complex plot lines of the 1971 original (Ooooh!) Firstly,what's going on with Keifer Sutherland's accent? I know he can't be Jack Bauer, but that was just bizarre (I am Senator Attius Corvus and this is the longest day of my life) Emily Browning (who I know is a decent actress) needed better lines than what was on offer here. Carrie Anne Moss had such a small part in this film, it wasn't worth her time & expertise (she must be desperate for a paycheck). I found the character of Atticus (Mr. Eko from Lost) was one of the few that I was rooting for in the film (the other was the lanista/gladiator owner just because he had some sense in trying to escape) - a good performance from him. Kit Harrington put in a competent performance as the slave Lurcio (renamed to Milo for this reboot) but I don't think he was tested any more than what he does playing Jon Snow (he even looks identical). He did take his top off for the ladies quite a bit (hence my friend's attendance) and gets 15 lashes if you are into that thing. To sum up the positives in this film, it didn't bore me and the effects were good. I also didn't hate the ending, but it was a bit cheesy! The scenes in the arena were good but nothing that rivals Ridley Scott's Gladiator . However, there were lots of detractors including people running away from a tsunami and surviving (how many people would have been saved in the last 10 years if they had done that?) Also, you can't outrun a lava flow from a volcano on a horse!

This adventure movie is based on a real event, the destruction of Pompeii by the eruption of Vesuvius in 79 AD. It is not meant to be a documentary about the event itself. As an adventure-romance it is excellent. Story, acting, and special effects all work well together to move the story along to the spectacular climax. It is irelevant whether the facts are accurately portrayed anymore than they are in Ben-hur, the Ten Commanments, or any other epic fictional piece. The only way to judge it is does it hold your attention, do you care about the characters, and is it enjoyable to see. In this, Pompeii exceeds the general run of the mill adventure movies and remains one of my favourites, whether or not it is factually correct,.

As someone who knows something about Roman culture and Pompeii, this film is difficult to watch.The faults this film makes concerning history are small, but still too present to just be ignored. For instance, the citizens of Pompeii didn't know they were living in the neighborhood of a volcano, because in their time mount Vesuvius looked like a mountain and not like a volcano. It had a top, which blew off when the volcano erupted becoming the debris that hid and covered Pompeii.Another example is the fact that according to Roman law, armies were not allowed to come into a city. In this film, it is clear, the makers do not know this.Also, talk about slaves as 'it' and 'savage' and 'dangerous to be around with alone' are modern projections of Roman life. Romans were fully conscious that slaves were people and made sure slaves could become free again if they behaved well. In fact, in Herculaneum, a town near Pompeii half of the population consisted of freed slaves. Furthermore this also shows an inconsistency within the story because the slave-friend of Cassia is almost shown as her equal.Lastly Pompeii was a Roman city and it is rather unhistorical to depict it as an annexed subservient province or someplace else discontent under Roman rule. Every province had its own representation within the function of a governor and most families, especially the rich ones, would consider themselves more Roman than Pompeian or anything other within the Roman Empire.To conclude, I think that this film is more of an attempt to depict current day populist visions on the Romans and societies of Antiquity ( slaves were not seen as human, women had it almost as bad as slaves, Romans were the big baddies, etc.) than real history.

As an avid movie go-er I was looking forward to seeing Pompeii- and was not disappointed. Many will say it was messy, going back and forth to a love story to a Gladiator themed movie, however it is just what this movie needed. Many are comparing Pompeii to Titanic, while the only similar aspect is a tragic love story. Before seeing this movie, be prepared for both story lines. I did not see the film in IMAX or 3D but I believe it did not take away from my experience. The CGI was flawless, I found myself on the edge of my seat for the majority of the movie. The casting was for the most part exceptional. Kit Harington is finding himself as an actor as he takes on a major lead role. I could see him doing more of these early BC/AC films as it is clearly his forte. He makes an awesome team with Adewale Akinnuoye-Agbaje. Their on screen friendly relationship has to be one of my favorites. Adewale's character stands out and easily becomes a fan favorite. Emily Browning as the lead female, I have to be honest. Her acting was fairly emotionless and I found it to be annoying at times, the expressions she made drove me crazy. Keifer Sutherland, amazing actor but not the role for him. He doesn't in the least bit even look Roman and his acting was very dry in this film. As for the story, you will find yourself captivated and intrigued there is no way you'd be able to walk out of the theater. I give Pompeii a 7/10. There were aspects I think could have been done better but overall very entertaining. The audience clapped at the end and several times during the film which makes it fun. I say give this film a fair shot and don't listen to the Titanic comparers.

Review title: Actually...not as bad as I expected
Review_body: I admit it: I watched this movie only because Kit Harington was in it (yeah, Jon Snow is my favorite in GoT so probably he'll end up killed...but this is another story). I expected an inaccurate, boring, cliché story about Pompeii and that was what I had, but in a weird way the movie wasn't so bad. Actually I liked it. First, I'd like to point out that the acting wasn't as horrid as everyone says: Emily Browning was a pleasant surprise. Second, I'd like to point out the accuracy in which the city was recreated. I found it immediately as I imagined it as I saw the remains a few years ago. Third, the thing I liked the most was the ending. I was half expecting them to escape (which I could like, but that I'd end up hating cause I am really fussy about History and when they mess up with it, I lose control), but the romantic/tragic ending suited the movie well. I found it was a good "twist" of the story since in Pompeii there are lovers giving each other a last kiss. It's sad but moving, cause in the end, after all that happened, they could manage to get together and to be together in eternity. Fourth, I liked the special effects. OK, every movie today has that kind of special effects, but these were really well done. In the end, I can't say this movie is a masterpiece, but all the people that are so negative about it had the wrong attitude in the theater, in my opinion. I expected nothing but a weak story and a sort of B-movie effects and everything, and I had better. So don't expect another Gladiator, but if you have the chance to see it, do it :)

This was a complete waste fo time. Here are the main reasons:1. The performance by the main characters was very poor and artificial. 2. The director did a bad job, as did the editor. 3. The main story is weak and uninspired. There are clichés all over the place. Dialogue is poor and boring. The whole story is completely dubious and it is hard to take the movie seriously. 4. Historically speaking, the film sacrifices the real events that occurred for the sake of extra special effects. The fact that two cities were destroyed before anything got to Pompeii is ignored completely. The 'fire rain' on Pompeii also never happened, as did the tsunami. It simply made no sense to add everything but the kitchen sink into this movie. 'The Gladiator' was fictional, but it never claimed to be anything else. This film claims to be based on real events, when it clearly isn't in the most important aspects of what happened that day. In Pompeii, people died because they inhaled the smoke, not because fire rained down on them or tsunamis washed them away. The arena (stadium) was never destroyed by the earhquake and it still stands in Pompeii to this day. Dubious to the extreme.Overall very very poor.

Review title: If only the studio didn't put a boy to do a man's job.
Review_body: While the special effects are up to expectations, the storyline is some sort typical but still bearable. Character development was deep enough though.Kit Harington in my point of view was a disappointment. Some said he was charming, maybe his curly hairs but he failed to charm me, not once. When Milo (Kit Harington) stands next to Atticus, oh my, you can clearly see a boy and a man. Atticus is every bit a masculine character. He is tall, dark and mighty, and that deep voice. As for Milo, he looked tiny compared not just to Atticus, but to most of the other warriors/gladiators. Never mind his size, Kit Harington however did not deliver a hero. He might have some muscles here and there and some fancy fighting moves but that's not enough. He does not have those eyes. Those eyes that tells you that he is the hero, and that he will make your time and money worthy. He does not have the edge, the charisma, the energy to lead the show. He does not speak like a hero. Let's not compare him with Brad Pitt in Troy, but I find myself wanting to see more of Atticus than Milo. Harington should just play Cassia's brother instead, riding a pony together. That would suit him a lot more.The movie is overall bearable if only the studio didn't put a boy to do a man's job.

Review title: Best Movie I've see in a long TIME
Review_body: I'm disappointed to see all the negative comments that people are giving to this movie. I thought it was one of the greatest movies I've ever seen. The editing and graphics were AMAZING! The plot was involving romance and action that was simply keeping my butt on the edge of my seat and me staring up at the screen with a stupid grin. The reason why people give so much hate cause it doesn't follow "exactly" what happened at the actual Pompeii. I know it's obvious that there was no meteorite shower, hailing rocks, or a freaking tsunami lol, but it made the movie better than I ever imagined it'd be. The graphics of everyone running and exploding back and forth made it so realistic.Even before the apocalyptic event of the eruption, the movie was already great and fast paced with action. I already fell in love with it and then realized that the big thing that I was waiting for hasn't even happened yet. I'm not giving away the ending but I thought the ending was awesome as well, no cliff hangers.I know that it was unrealistic to the actual Pompeii but where does it say in the description, "Based on True Events" id say that if they did do exactly how it happened, where a big cloud of ash just came down in two minutes and buried everyone, then it'd be really boring. The apocalyptic part lasted at least the majority of the movie which was great!!So to conclude this, I have to disagree with all the hate and ask other viewers that this is actually one of the best movie out now and I totally recommend it to everyone. 9 out of 10 stars all the way!!

Review title: Loved It and I Will Not Apologize For It!!
Review_body: I just saw the movie and yes it was a guilty pleasure but I was impressed with the cast. Exception Kiefer Sutherland looked absolutely uncomfortable in this role and his speech was like a tongue in cheek caricature villain but carried off so poorly it made me wince. Being a huge fan of Game of Thrones, the draw was Kit Harrington and I thought his understated performance was absolutely perfect. Speaking with his eyes to convey his emotion was believable and made the romance thus. His emotional scars did not make him a smooth talker which it seems other reviews were casting a negative spotlight on. I loved the ending! I thought the cast of actors I had never seen before did a terrific job, Cassia, Atticus and Kiefer 's right hand man and Cassia's maid servant in particular. The focus on lack of historical accuracy is not fair and this is certainly not the first nor last film to be in this category . I highly recommend this film as A showcase of a person 's resilience to overcome tragedy, an understated romance which is actually refreshing and old-fashioned and a friendship between Milo and Atticus which was I thought heartfelt. And of course the special effects! See the movie and judge for yourself! I loved it and if just a different actor for Senator Corvus... even more so! And what Kit did physically amazing and puts him in the same league as Christian Bale, Jarred Leto etc!
